title: Help please: dual absorption nlmixr model (first+zero)
body:
Hello, 
I was trying to fit a dual absorption model using the dataset that shows dual absorption.
I have tried:
1. Zero-order absorption followed by the first-order absorption 
2. First-order absorption followed by zero-order absorption

The first model (Zero + first) seems to work fine, but somehow, the second model does not recognize parameter ALAG2 
So, I also made another dataset that includes both ALAG1 and ALAG2 and fitted to the first model (Zero+first) and it seems to estimate the ALAG2 parameter. 

I have been stuck with this problem forever. Would be so appreciated if I could get some help, please. 
I have attached the dataset as well. 

This is the first-model;
```R
#### 1-comp Dual (Zero+first) absorption and First-order elimination ####

dat <- read.csv("1-comp_zf.csv") %>% 
  filter(time==0) %>% 
  mutate(AMT = 100000, RATE = -2, CMT = 2) 

data <- read.csv("1-comp_zf.csv") %>% 
  filter(time==0) %>% 
  mutate(AMT = 100000, RATE = 0, CMT = 1) %>% 
  rbind(dat)

data_dual <- read.csv("1-comp_zf.csv") %>% 
  mutate(AMT = 0, RATE = 0, CMT = 2) %>% 
  rbind(data) %>% 
  filter(time %in% c(0, 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24)) %>% 
  rename(DV = CP, TIME = time) %>% 
  arrange(ID,TIME,RATE,CMT)


Z301 <- function() {
  ini({
    tka    <- log(c(0,1))
    tcl    <- log(c(0,10))
    tv     <- log(c(0,100))
    tD2    <- log(c(0,2))
    tf1    <- log(c(0,0.5,1))
    talag1 <- log(c(0,6))
    
    eta.ka ~ 0.1
    eta.cl ~ 0.1
    eta.v  ~ 0.1
    
    prop.err <- 0.1
  })
  
  model({
    KA    <- exp(tka + eta.ka)
    CL    <- exp(tcl + eta.cl)
    VC    <- exp(tv  + eta.v)
    D2    <- exp(tD2)
    F1    <- exp(tf1)
    ALAG1 <- exp(talag1)
    
    K20 = CL/VC
    S2 = VC
    
    d/dt(A1) = -KA*A1
    alag(A1) = ALAG1
    d/dt(A2) = KA*A1 - K20*A2
    dur(A2)  = D2
    f(A1) <- F1
    f(A2) <- 1-F1
    CP = A2/S2
    CP ~ prop(prop.err)
    
  })
}
```

Second model I am stuck with...

```r
#### 1-comp Dual (First+zero) absorption and First-order elimination ####

dat <- read.csv("1-comp_zf.csv") %>% 
  filter(time==0) %>% 
  mutate(AMT = 100000, RATE = -2, CMT = 2) 

data <- read.csv("1-comp_zf.csv") %>% 
  filter(time==0) %>% 
  mutate(AMT = 100000, RATE = 0, CMT = 1) %>% 
  rbind(dat)

data_dual <- read.csv("1-comp_zf.csv") %>% 
  mutate(AMT = 0, RATE = 0, CMT = 2) %>% 
  rbind(data) %>% 
  filter(time %in% c(0, 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24)) %>% 
  rename(DV = CP, TIME = time) %>% 
  arrange(ID,TIME,CMT, RATE)


Z201 <- function() {
  ini({
    tka    <- log(c(0,3))
    tcl    <- log(c(0,5))
    tv     <- log(c(0,100))
    tD2    <- log(c(0,1))
    tf1    <- log(c(0,0.5,1))
    talag2 <- log(c(0,6))
    

    eta.ka ~ 0.1
    eta.cl ~ 0.1
    eta.v  ~ 0.1
    
    prop.err <- 0.1
  })
  
  model({
    KA    <- exp(tka + eta.ka)
    CL    <- exp(tcl + eta.cl)
    VC    <- exp(tv + eta.v)
    D2    <- exp(tD2)
    F1    <- exp(tf1)
    ALAG2 <- exp(talag2)
    
    K20 = CL/VC
    S2 = VC
    
    d/dt(A1) = -KA*A1
    d/dt(A2) = KA*A1 - K20*A2
    dur(A2)  = D2
    alag(A2) = ALAG2
    f(A1) <- F1
    f(A2) <- 1-F1
    CP = A2/S2
    CP ~ prop(prop.err)
    
  })
}
```

[dataset.zip](https://github.com/nlmixrdevelopment/nlmixr/files/6645852/dataset.zip)

title: Proposed feature: abbreviate variable names <= 8 chars
body:
Greetings, thanks for sharing your work with the greater pharma industry! Maybe I can help contribute: I've done some work on prepping [sas v5 transport files](https://documentation.sas.com/doc/en/pgmsascdc/9.4_3.5/movefile/n1xbwdre0giahfn11c99yjkpi2yb.htm) in my current role with Biogen. Specifically, via a pkg & shiny app that automatically abbreviates variables names <= 8.

To augment the package beyond just checking for <=8 chars, I'd be willing to contribute function called `xportr_var_rename()` or something similar that takes the `var_spec` object and performs an abbreviation algorithm, where each variable would be renamed using the least intrusive method possible (to maintain originality) to achieve <=8 chars. If you think it's within scope of the `xportr` package, please let me know!

Here's an example of my function as it works today, using some clinical variable names and again, using randomly generated sentences:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17878953/122124234-01781900-cdfd-11eb-88dd-2655c4e10c03.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17878953/122123854-89115800-cdfc-11eb-81b6-1806718bfcb2.png)

title: Add in the packages score on a risk metric
body:
## Idea

Could we track the 'trust worthiness' of the package as a badge? e.g.  calculate risk metric score and show it as a badge? 

## Steps

Add riskmetric to cicd - and expose as badge (if no badge service exists I guess could just write a svg via the gh action).

## Concern

Is the score designed to be used on a single package? e.g. what does '0.8' mean to an end user?

It's also easy for us to game the number by looking at the categories - although maybe that also increases the quality of the package so is ok?

title: analyze_colvars header is not aligned in html format
body:
```r
library(rtables)
library(dplyr)
ANL <- DM %>% mutate(value = rnorm(n()), pctdiff = runif(n()))

## toy example where we take the mean of the first variable and the
## count of >.5 for the second.
colfuns <- list(function(x) rcell(mean(x), format = "xx.x"),
                function(x) rcell(sum(x > .5), format = "xx"))

l <- basic_table() %>%
  split_cols_by("ARM") %>%
  split_cols_by_multivar(c("value", "pctdiff")) %>%
  split_rows_by("RACE", split_label = "ethnicity", split_fun = drop_split_levels) %>%
  summarize_row_groups() %>%
  analyze_colvars(afun = colfuns)

build_table(l, ANL) %>% Viewer()

```
The result looks fine in the console but in html format, ~the last 3 columns are missing~ the columns and header are not aligned.

author: waddella

title: make a staged dependency graph and text output
body:
# Graph

It would be good for any package that has a `staged_dependencies.yaml` file to allow to create a dependency graph that includes only other packages mentioned in the `staged_dependencies.yaml` files (recursively):

![staged dependencies (4)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7786462/123103833-aa92c500-d436-11eb-9e35-428cc8781b68.png)

# Text output

Also, for command line use it would be good to add the `internal_dependencies` function that would look as follows:

```
staged_dependencies()

current branch: 01_fix@devel

repo        branch             rel
-------------------------------------------
B           devel               upstream
A           devel               upstream
C           01_fix@devel        upstream
D           01_fix@devel        current
E           devel               downstream
F           01_fix@devel        downstream
G           devel               downstream
H           devel               other
I           01_fix@devel        other
J           devel               other
K           devel               other
L           devel               downstream
```

Note the return object should be a `data.frame`.

title: token matching
body:
please update the code and `README.md` to support a token lookup table. That is, I suggest to add an entry in `options` with a default mapping

```
options(staged.depencencies.token_mapping = c(
    "https://github.com" = "GITHUB_PAT", 
    "https://gitlab.com" = "GITLAB_PAT"
))
```

and then the user can modify it in the `.Rprofile`

title: check if this works with renv
body: not that renv modifies the libpath with a project local `.Rprofile`, so make sure that `R CMD INSTALL` for upstream uses an R process relativ to the active project. I suggest that when you call `install_upstream` you get the current `.libPaths` and then use the `-l` argument for `R`.

title: local repos
body:
add a `local` argument that takes a data.frame with 3 columns (repo, host, local_path) so that the user can use local clones for checking and installation (i.e. working on a repo spanning feature locally). The `local` argument should be `NULL` by default, i.e. getting all the dependencies from the remotes.


# In the RStudio addin

Then you can ask which rrepo to use locally and store the default local repo mapping in the file `~/.staged_dependencies/config`

```
repo, host, local_path
Roche/rtables, https://github.com, ~/git_projects/rtables
```

title: r2rtf needs to work properly with `group_by`
body:
```
### Preliminaries
rm(list=ls())
require(tidyverse)
require(r2rtf)

# Get data from package
dat <- select(r2rtf_adsl, SUBJID, ARM, SEX, AGEGR1, WEIGHTBL)

# Calculate mean weight by ARM and SEX
stats <- dat %>% group_by(ARM, SEX, AGEGR1) %>% summarize(N=n(), WEIGHT.MEAN=mean(WEIGHTBL))

# New header
hdr <- c("Arm | Gender | Age Group | N Subjects | Weight")

# Doesn't update header
stats %>%
  rtf_colheader(colheader = hdr, text_format="b") %>%
  rtf_body() %>%
  rtf_encode() %>%
  write_rtf(file = "rtf_colheader_test1.rtf")

# Updates header
as_tibble(stats) %>%
rtf_colheader(colheader = hdr, text_format="b") %>%
rtf_body() %>%
rtf_encode() %>%
write_rtf(file = "rtf_colheader_test2.rtf")
```

title: rtables::as_html duplicates the first row cells when split_cols_by_multivar is used with more than one variable.
body:
rtables::as_html duplicates the first row cells when split_cols_by_multivar is used with more than one variable.

```r
library(rtables)
lyt <- basic_table() %>%
  split_cols_by("am") %>%
  split_cols_by_multivar(vars = c("disp", "hp"))
result <- build_table(lyt = lyt, df = mtcars)

print(result)
print(rtables::as_html(result))
```

The outputs:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24480246/123417953-bdcd9e00-d5b8-11eb-88e8-060b9ab5fc0f.png)

Notice that the cells in the first row of `result` span two cells of other columns. Meanwhile, rtables::as_html returns an HTML table, in which the first row spans double the number of other rows. In essence, I would expect a result to be this:
```html
...
  <tr class="">
    <th class="" style="white-space:pre;"></th>
    <th class=" text-center" colspan="2">1</th>
    <th class=" text-center" colspan="2">0</th>
  </tr>
...
```
author: kpagacz

title: Any approah modeling PK-binominal PD or PK-ordered categorical PD data in nlmixr?
body:
Hi@mattfidler, recently I'd like to model the PK-adverse event model to demonstrate the exposure-safety relaionship. The preliminary approach was to first do popPK modeling, then have individual exposure prediction, and finally link individual exposure to adverse events using logistic regression or survival analysis. However, such approach disconnected PK and PD, and if logistic regression is used the time information of events is ignored.

Then I would like to try joint PK-PD model which incorporating individual predicted PK parameters and observed PD events with time record, which is PK-categorical PD model. As far as I know the ensence of such approach is to redefine the likelihood function as those in NONMEM. However, I have no idea whether it could be resolved in nlmixr. If it is allowed, could you please tell me how to handle this?

author: billdenney

title: linCmt() Detection Issue?
body:
I just tried to make a 2-compartment linear compartmental model using `linCmt()`, but when I looked at the summary output, it said that it was a 1-compartment model.  Am I doing something wrong or is there a typo in the printout for the model?

The specific line below is "RxODE-based 1-compartment model with first-order absorption" which I thought should say "2-compartment" instead of "1-compartment".

``` r
library(nlmixr)
twocmt <- function() {
  ini({
    lKA <- 0.1      ; label("Ka (1/hr)")
    lCl <- 1.6      ; label("Cl (L/hr)")
    lVc <- log(18)  ; label("Vc (L)")
    lVp <- log(22)  ; label("Vp (L)")
    lQ  <- log(2)   ; label("Q (L/hr)")
    eta_KA ~ 0.1 ; label("BSV Ka")
    eta_Cl ~ 0.1 ; label("BSV Cl")
    eta_Vc ~ 0.1 ; label("BSV Vc")
    prop.err <- c(0, 0.2, 1)
  })
  model({
    KA <- exp(lKA + eta_KA)
    Cl <- exp(lCl + eta_Cl)
    Vc <- exp(lVc + eta_Vc)
    Vp <- exp(lVp)
    Q <- exp(lQ)
    linCmt() ~ prop(prop.err)
  })
}

nlmixr(twocmt)
#> __ RxODE-based 1-compartment model with first-order absorption _________________ 
#> -- Initialization: ------------------------------------------------------------- 
#> Fixed Effects ($theta): 
#>       lKA       lCl       lVc       lVp        lQ 
#> 0.1000000 1.6000000 2.8903718 3.0910425 0.6931472 
#> 
#> Omega ($omega): 
#>        eta_KA eta_Cl eta_Vc
#> eta_KA    0.1    0.0    0.0
#> eta_Cl    0.0    0.1    0.0
#> eta_Vc    0.0    0.0    0.1
#> -- mu-referencing ($muRefTable): ----------------------------------------------- 
#>   theta    eta
#> 1   lKA eta_KA
#> 2   lCl eta_Cl
#> 3   lVc eta_Vc
#> 
#> -- Model: ---------------------------------------------------------------------- 
#>     KA <- exp(lKA + eta_KA)
#>     Cl <- exp(lCl + eta_Cl)
#>     Vc <- exp(lVc + eta_Vc)
#>     Vp <- exp(lVp)
#>     Q <- exp(lQ)
#>     linCmt() ~ prop(prop.err) 
#> ________________________________________________________________________________
```

title: Feature suggestion: blq_trans for showing measurements below the LLOQ
body:
This is related to kestrel99/pmxTools#23 (more accurately, it replaces that).  It is also related to #21.

**Describe the feature**
Plotting values below the LLOQ with ggplot does not always clearly represent the data.  A specific issue relates to the fact that zeros on the log scale are on the axis and difficult to observe.

The features are described with the example below:

``` r
# Loading the local copy of the code from the PR
source("c:/git/Not_my_repositories/xgxr/R/blq_trans.R")
library(tidyverse)

# First, a normal plot
ggplot(data=data.frame(x=1:10, y=1:10), aes(x=x, y=y)) +
  geom_point()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/NU3OK4w.png)

``` r
# Data are censored to 0.5*LLOQ, and the axis text shows "<[LLOQ value]" rather
# than a number
ggplot(data=data.frame(x=1:10, y=1:10), aes(x=x, y=y)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(trans=blq_trans(lloq=3))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/SFTGtM2.png)

``` r
# If you prefer a different location than 0.5*LLOQ, you can provide that with
# the multiplier
ggplot(data=data.frame(x=1:10, y=1:10), aes(x=x, y=y)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(trans=blq_trans(lloq=3, multiplier=0.9))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/OMvJkQd.png)

``` r
# If you prefer different text than "<[LLOQ value]", you can provide that with
# the lloq_text argument
ggplot(data=data.frame(x=1:10, y=1:10), aes(x=x, y=y)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(trans=blq_trans(lloq=3, multiplier=0.9, lloq_text="BLQ plotting is handy"))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/eQThFk6.png)

``` r
# It can work for both axes simultaneously
ggplot(data=data.frame(x=1:10, y=1:10), aes(x=x, y=y)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(trans=blq_trans(lloq=3)) +
  scale_y_continuous(trans=blq_trans(lloq=3))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/10MCw1N.png)

``` r
# Log scale works, too (with blq_log_trans)
ggplot(data=data.frame(x=1:10, y=1:10), aes(x=x, y=y)) +
  geom_point() +
  scale_x_continuous(trans=blq_log_trans(lloq=3))
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/3ufBBfm.png)

<sup>Created on 2021-07-01 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.0)</sup>

title: Development Idea: Library of model snippets and model expansion
body:
Somewhat related to #540

To be very clear from the outset, I think that this would likely reside in another package than nlmixr, but it would be very tightly related.  One common naming syntax for packages like this is something like `nlmixrExtra`.

My thought here is something like an `nlmixr_tran()` function that would perform pre-processing of models to expand commonly-used model structures.

```r
library(nlmixrExtra)
onecmt <- function() {
  ini({
    lCl <- 1.6
    lVc <- log(18)
    lVmax <- log(0.1)
    lC50 <- log(100)
    eta_Cl ~ 0.1
    prop_err <- c(0, 0.2, 1)
  })
  model({
    Cl <- exp(lCl + eta_Cl)
    Vc <- exp(lVc)
    Vmax <- exp(lVmax)
    mm_c50 <- exp(lC50)
    cp <- TMDD_Michaelis_Menten(CL=Cl, Vc=Vc, Vmax=Vmax, C50=mm_c50, compartment=central)
    cp ~ prop(prop_err)
  })
}
onecmt_expanded <- nlmixr_tran(onecmt)
```

`nlmixr_tran()` would modify the model and return that modified model (or perhaps go ahead and call nlmixr with that modified model if `estimate=TRUE` or something like that).

The output of `onecmt_expanded` would expand out the `linear_pk()` function to look like:

```r
function() {
  ini({
    lCl <- 1.6
    lVc <- log(18)
    lVmax <- log(0.1)
    lC50 <- log(100)
    eta_Cl ~ 0.1
    prop_err <- c(0, 0.2, 1)
  })
  model({
    Cl <- exp(lCl + eta_Cl)
    Vc <- exp(lVc)
    Vmax <- exp(lVmax)
    mm_c50 <- exp(lC50)
    d/dt(central) = -central*Cl/Vc - central*Vmax/(central/Vc + mm_c50)
    cp <- central/Vc
    cp ~ prop(prop_err)
  })
}
```

With an expansion mechanism (as suggested with `nlmixr_trans()`), it would be comparatively straight-forward to make the substitution functions like `TMDD_Michaelis_Menten()`.
author: billdenney

title: Feature Request: linCmt() on the right hand side with less automation
body:
I have a model where I want to simultaneously use two `linCmt()` PK models while fitting the PD model.  But, I think that `linCmt()` is only valid on the left hand side of an error model assignment (i.e. `linCmt() ~ prop(prop.err)`).

The feature request here has a few different parts to attempt to have the goal of using it for different drugs in the same model.

1. Can `linCmt()` go on the right hand side of an assignment statement (e.g. `cp = linCmt()`)?  Maybe it already can, but I have not seen documentation of an example of that.
2. Can a new version of linCmt be made where it can accept named arguments rather than auto-detecting the parameters?  The goal of this part is that you could work with more than one drug at a time.  (This is a bit different than using DVID or some other method like that because of the idea that I may want to work with more than one `linCmt()` drug at the same time.  If I need to do a calculation like `cp_drug1 = linCmt([parameters for drug 1])`, `cp_drug2 = linCmt([parameters for drug 2])`, and then some calculation with `cp_drug1` and `cp_drug2` such as a competitive Emax model, I can't immediately think of a way to do that.)

An example of what I'd like to be able to do is below.

```r
library(nlmixr)
double_onecmt <- function() {
  ini({
    lCl1 <- 1.6      ; label("Cl drug 1 (L/hr)")
    lVc1 <- log(18)  ; label("Vc drug 1 (L)")
    eta_Cl1 ~ 0.1 ; label("BSV Cl drug 1 ")
    prop_err1 <- c(0, 0.2, 1)
    lCl2 <- 1.6      ; label("Cl drug 2 (L/hr)")
    lVc2 <- log(18)  ; label("Vc drug 2 (L)")
    eta_Cl2 ~ 0.1 ; label("BSV Cl drug 2")
    prop_err2 <- c(0, 0.2, 1)
  })
  model({
    Cl1 <- exp(lCl1 + eta_Cl1)
    Vc1 <- exp(lVc1)
    Cl2 <- exp(lCl2 + eta_Cl2)
    Vc2 <- exp(lVc2)
    cp1 <- linCmt(CL=Cl1, Vc=Vc1)
    cp2 <- linCmt(CL=Cl2, Vc=Vc2)
    cp1 ~ prop(prop_err1)
    cp2 ~ prop(prop_err2)
  })
}
nlmixr(double_onecmt)
```

author: waddella

title: Update with tibble 3.1.0 breaks read_hf
body:
Thanks to @dawnye for this report in https://github.com/atorus-research/CDISC_pilot_replication/issues/7.

With tibble 3.1.0 even `my_tibble[FALSE, "notAColumn"] <- 1` will result in a new column being created. This is [intended behavior](https://github.com/tidyverse/tibble/issues/846) for tibble now. This breaks `fill_missing_data()` which is an unexported function in read_hf.R. This is the offending line:
```
 .data[is.na(.data[var]), var] <- correct_defaults(var)
```
`correct_defaults` returns NULL when var is 'type'. This would never happen in an actual hf_file but even if it returns null, tibble is trying to add a new column and failing because its not a vector, a bare list, a data frame or a matrix.

Thankfully this is an easy fix. Either add type as a option in the `correct_defaults` as a blank matrix, or add an if statement like the following:
```
if(any(is.na(.data[[var]]))
          .data[is.na(.data[[var]]), var] <- correct_defaults(var)

author: zmeers

title: Class hierarchy of pkg_remote isn't maintained
body:
Thanks to a bug report, #206 - it looks like our recent overhaul of the class constructors (#203) dropped some of the intermediate classes needed for metric inheritance.

Using the example in that bug report,

```r
pkg_visR <- pkg_ref("visR")  # when not installed
class(pkg_visR)
#> # produces:
#> c("pkg_cran_remote", "pkg_ref", "environment") 
#> # expect:
#> c("pkg_cran_remote", "pkg_remote", "pkg_ref", "environment") 
```

As described in `?pkg_ref`, we expect that `pkg_remote` is a superclass of `pkg_cran_remote`, `pkg_bioc_remote` and `pkg_git_remote`. 

Because of this, many metrics for cran and biocondcutor remotes fail to inherit generic metrics implemented for `pkg_remote`s.

Create a vignette with information from [Box.com slide deck](https://exbpbox.ent.box.com/file/812035970361?s=60x2ahhbyt7jn05kiqaptir58ddgzril), which is updated as part of issue #316
author: duniek

title: Fix an oversight in classes applied to pkg_ref when source is explicitly provided
body:
As reported in #206 & isolated in #207, a user discovered an issue where `pkg_remote` methods weren't being dispatched upon because this superclass was omitted from `pkg_*_remote` subclasses. 

I added in a programmatically accessible class hierarchy (nested list) which is traversed in search of valid `source` classes, and applies the entire class hierarchy to the resulting object. eg

```r
class(pkg_ref("mypkg", source = "pkg_cran_remote"))
#> c("pkg_cran_remote", "pkg_remote", "pkg_ref", "environment")

class(pkg_ref("mypkg", source = "pkg_install"))
#> c("pkg_install", "pkg_ref", "environment")
```

Only concern I have with this approach is allowing users to extend with their own subclasses, but we can cross that bridge when we get there. I don't see any demand for that functionality quite yet. 

@elimillera - would you mind taking a look since most of the changes affect code that was introduced in #203?

Closes #206, #207

---

Since this is actually a fairly crippling bug for remote package refs, I think this might warrant a resubmission to CRAN for the patch release.
author: dgkf

title: testthat file dedicated to verify compliance with CRAN guidelines
body:
This test automatically scans the relevant parts of our codebase for possible violations of additional style guidelines we received during the CRAN submission process. Generally, a list of files is retrieved which is then searched analysed using a regex pattern specific to the respective issue. If found, the test fails and the file and line of the issue are printed into the test log.

```
# Specifications ---------------------------------------------------------------
#' T1. Our codebase doesn't violate CRAN style-guidelines.
#' T1.1 TRUE/FALSE are used instead of T/F.
#' T1.2 Each function documentation contains a \value{} tag.
#' T1.3 The existence of packages is not checked through 'installed.packages()'.
#' T1.4 No \dontrun{} tags unless the code actually takes a long time.
#' T1.5 The use of 'options()' is immediately preemptively reverted.
```

title: `text_format` issue with all value equal to `""`
body:
An error below shall be avoid. 

```
library(r2rtf)

f <- rep("", ncol(iris))

iris %>% 
  rtf_body(text_format = f)
```

hot fix: 

```
library(r2rtf)

f <- rep("", ncol(iris))

if(all(f == "")) f <- NULL

iris %>% 
  rtf_body(text_format = f)
```
author: elong0527

title: Templates feedback (2-3h)
body:
* I would rather use `saveRDS` instead of `save` at the end of the templates. `load` (pair function to `save`) assigns by a side-effect, making it dangerous because it can overwrite existing objects without notice. `my_data <- readRDS` is safer.

* The use of `case_when` function: `!is.na` in the first case in the example below is irrelevant, it either needs to be used explicitly everywhere, or nowhere, or as a single clause:
  ```
  format_agegr1 <- function(x) {
    case_when(
      !is.na(x) & x < 18 ~ "< 18",
      x >= 18 & x < 65 ~ "18 - 65",
      x >= 65 ~ ">= 65"
    )
  }
  ```

  The two calls have the same result: 
  ```
  format_agegr2 <- function(x) {
    case_when(
      x < 18 ~ "< 18",  
      x >= 18 & x < 65 ~ "18 - 65",
      x >= 65 ~ ">= 65"
    )
  }
  format_agegr1(c(NA,10,20))
  format_agegr2(c(NA,10,20))
  ```
  See the examples of `?case_when` for further details. There are multiple cases of this throughout the package.

* We now have templates (inst/templates) and example scripts (inst/example_scripts). The difference between those two is minor so I would suggest to use templates instead of example scripts everywhere. Anyway, the example scripts are only used as a reference in vignettes and in data:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22340537/124899679-a5aa4580-dfe0-11eb-98d3-e097e177dd78.png)
author: slamao

title: Better api for specifying column location in tables with nested columns
body:
It would be nice to be able to specify exactly which columns to select when extracting info with `row_values`. Example:

```r
> tbl <- basic_table() %>%
+   split_cols_by("ARM") %>%
+   split_cols_by("STRATA2") %>%
+   analyze("AEDECOD") %>%
+   build_table(ex_adae, ex_adsl)
> 
> first_row <- collect_leaves(tbl[1,])[[1]]
> vals <- row_values(first_row)
> vals
$`A: Drug X.S1`
[1] 31

$`A: Drug X.S2`
[1] 33

$`B: Placebo.S1`
[1] 29

$`B: Placebo.S2`
[1] 33

$`C: Combination.S1`
[1] 32

$`C: Combination.S2`
[1] 56
```

Using column names or paths would be nicer than extracting values by index.

author: kpl05

title: Error: linCmt are not supported in RxODE
body:
Based on the discussion in #540, I thought the following was allowed.  Can you please help me understand how to use linCmt on the right hand side?

``` r
library(nlmixr)

nlmixr_onecmt_fixed <- function() {
  ini({
    tcl <- log(c(0, .1, 10)) ; label("Clearance (L/kg/hr)")
    tv <- log(0.1); label("log V (L/kg)")
    add_sd <- 0.7
  })
  model({
    cl <- exp(tcl)
    v <- exp(tv)
    # unit conversion
    cp <- linCmt()*1000/v
    cp ~ add(add_sd)
  })
}

fit <- nlmixr(nlmixr_onecmt_fixed, data=theo_sd, control=list(print=0), est="focei")
#> > creating full model...
#> > pruning branches (`if`/`else`)...
#> v done
#> > loading into symengine environment...

author: anajens

title: bug fix for text_format = ""

author: elong0527

title: How to integrate metrics from other packages?
body:
As the audience of `riskmetric` grows, we're seeing new packages that offer really compelling metrics, but might introduce new dependencies, drastically increase runtime or only apply in niche applications. One of our design goals has always been extensibility, yet we don't have any concrete examples of how a package might extend riskmetric. 

I've added the [Package Integration](https://github.com/pharmaR/riskmetric/labels/Package%20Integration) label to track our backlog specific to packages which may want to register metrics with `riskmetric`. 

## Design

### Option 1: All metrics created in `riskmetric`

Perhaps the most straightforward solution is just to implement metrics within `riskmetric`. However, this would bloat our dependency footprint and runtimes meaning that we may want to build more interfaces to restricting which sets of metrics get run. 

### Option 2: All metrics created in `riskmetric`, but only run if `Suggests` dependency is installed

As a way of mitigating this management, perhaps we could only turn on these behaviors when those dependencies are available. However, this feels like an enormous amount of dependency management, which really should be handled by the package installation instead.

### Option 3: Offshoot packages (eg, `riskmetric.<use case>`)

Alternatively, we could develop more focused packages - perhaps by theme such as `riskmetric.security`, or by package that is integrated such as `riskmetric.srr`or `riskmetric.autotest`. This would let us fragment metrics among a few different extension packages so that specific metric classes or packages handle all the bookkeeping for their own dependencies.

### Option 4: Encourage packages to refer to `riskmetric` via `Enhances`

I think the devil might be in the details with this one, but we could aim to make it as easy as possible for other packages to register metrics that enhance `riskmetric` - possibly without even taking on a direct dependency since all of our extensions operate through S3 dispatch. I think this could be the most comfortable way to encourage extensions and we could rely on a canonical way of tracking enhancement via the DESCRIPTION `Enhances` field. I think a proof-of-concept would be needed to make sure this is feasible before encouraging this path forward, though. 

### Option ... ? 

Open to suggestions.

## Action Items

Whatever path we take, I think we could use a new vignette showing how to integrate new metrics that bring niche or intensive metrics to `riskmetric`.
author: dgkf

title: Integration with `goodpractice`
body:
[`goodpractice`](https://github.com/MangoTheCat/goodpractice) looks like it covers a whole litany of best practices that are often a good heuristic for developers familiarity with software development practices, even if many of these decisions don't inherently mean that a package is of poor quality. This can be an excellent quick measure of package quality.

---

Please refer to #209 to help consider how package integrations should be managed
author: dgkf

title: Integration with `pkgnet`
body:
[`pkgnet`](https://github.com/uptake/pkgnet) provides a few cool analyses that might be useful for surfacing as metrics. Both dependency graphs, as well as within-package function graphs. For example, I believe we could use various graph metrics such as a hub or authority score to weight the importance of function unit test coverage, offering new ways to present weighted sums of function coverage that might better reflect how those functions are used. 

---

Please refer to #209 to help consider how package integrations should be managed
author: dgkf

title: Integrations with `oysteR`
body:
Thanks @csgillespie for reaching out at useR! - This looks like a really cool package to integrate with. 

[`oysteR`](https://github.com/sonatype-nexus-community/oysteR/) looks like an awesome resource for identifying security vulnerabilities in packages. From a brief readthrough, it looks like it compares a package against the [Sonatype OSS Index](https://ossindex.sonatype.org/), identifying known vulnerabilities. 

---

Please refer to #209 to help consider how package integrations should be managed
author: dgkf

title: Integrations with `valtools`
body:
PhUSE's [`valtools`](https://github.com/phuse-org/valtools/) represents a way of linking requirements as roxygen tags through to unit tests as a way of building a traceability matrix to ensure that proclaimed package specification requirements are met and tested. 

This is a bit of a different lens through which to interpret unit testing that isn't covered by canonical measures such as code coverage. 

---

Please refer to #209 to help consider how package integrations should be managed
author: dgkf

title: Integrations with ROpenSci's `autotest`
body:
@mpadge has been cranking out awesome package analytics tools this past year, and it might be high-time that we start pulling them in! 

Just to recap, [`autotest`](https://github.com/ropensci-review-tools/autotest) stresses functions by throwing randomized inputs at it aiming to catch edge cases that can be easy to overlook during development (eg negative values, missingness, other similar classes). I'm sure I'm still oversimplifying things, but nevertheless this would be a great measure for package function stability/resilience. 

---

Please refer to #209 to help consider how package integrations should be managed
author: dgkf

title: Integrations with ROpenSci's `srr`
body:
I'm still learning about @mpadge's `srr`, but I think there might be some opportunities for metrics here. Perhaps to measure the adherence to statistical development best practices and documented reference implementations. 

Perhaps as we start to see `srr` being adopted in new packages we might have a more tangible example of what metrics are important and we can start to think about how to surface those through `riskmetric`. 

---

Please refer to #209 to help consider how package integrations should be managed
author: dgkf

title: Pagination exact line count issue
body:
Posted initially as comment in #197 by @anajens

Thanks @gmbecker for the nice examples! I've had a chance to play around some more and things are working nicely. I found one case where the pagination does not quite work. I wonder if there are additional tests pagination features need to work with referential footnotes? For example:

```r
analysisfun2 <- function(x, cutoff,  ...) {
  mn <- mean(x)
  if(mn >= cutoff)
    cf = list(mean = "Elevated group mean")
  else
    cf = list()
  in_rows(mean = mean(x),
          range = range(x),
          .row_footnotes = list(range = "range footnote"),
          .cell_footnotes = cf,
          .formats = list(mean = "xx.x", range = "xx - xx"))
}
lyt2 <- basic_table(
  title = "title",
  subtitles = "xx",
  main_footer = "footer"
  ) %>%
  split_cols_by("ARM") %>%
  analyze("AGE", afun = analysisfun2, extra_args = list(cutoff = mean(ex_adsl$AGE))) %>%
  analyze("COUNTRY")
tbl <- build_table(lyt2, ex_adsl)
tbl

export_as_txt(tbl, "t_ref_footers.txt", paginate = TRUE)
```

`tbl` looks good
```

xx

But trying to paginate gives error:

author: yesimiao

title: Deprecate insert_rrow support for TableTree objects?
body:
When analyzing the behavior in #202 a number of problematic corner cases for `insert_rrow` in non-trivial tables occurred to me. While we can easily continue to support `insert_rrow` for `ElementaryTable` objects, its not clear we can in the general case in a way that is both coherent and likely to be useful rather than confusing to the user.

# Ambiguities

## LabelRow in position that does not correspond to a substructure

Currently this works, and a labelrow is placed whre a DataRow would have been, but I am fairly confident this is ultimately a broken table structure. Even if it is not, it is will make retrieving the cell values of the table or subtable not have the expected dimensions.

## LabelRow in a position where multiple subtables with non-visible label rows are present between two visible rows.

This is ambiguous. We could choose to always do minimum depth or always maximum depth from amongst the options, but those will have very different resulting indentation structures and its not clear one or the other is always what the user will want.

## Label row at a position where a visible label row already exists in the structure

I don't think it should replace the existing label, as this is an insert operation, but if we put it in as a normal child we have the same issues we did above. 

## DataRow in position that spans structural breaks

This is supported now, and is "greedy", ie it will always be the last sibling of the previous row rather than the first sibling of the trailing row corresponding to the position. This is "correct" in that it avoids issues where the trailing row is a label, and thus cannot have a preceeding direct sibling that is a Data row, but it is also not unambiguously what the user is going to want.

There may be others.

Thoughts @anajens @waddella @danielinteractive ?

author: waddella

title: Question/Documentation Request:  How are output columns calculated in the presence of censoring?
body:
I have mouse tumor growth data that I am modeling.  With it, I have low censoring (<1 mm^3 is considered censored) and high censoring (after euthanasia, the tumor is bigger than it was at euthanasia).

It's not exactly clear to me how the output columns are calculated in censored results.  Is this documented somewhere, and is there a better way to calculate them?

What I think I'm seeing based on the outputs in my model are:

* DV: cumulative distribution function value at IPRED
* IPRED: value of the measurement (estimated actual value, not probability density estimate)
* IRES: DV - IPRED
* IWRES: IRES/[residual error model standard deviation]

I would have thought that the following would be the column outputs

* DV: simply copying over the DV from the input dataset
* IPRED: cumulative distribution function since it is a censored row
* IRES and IWRES would likely be missing since given the above two, DV and IPRED would not be comparable

title: rtables - cell numerical (fraction) output alignment
body:
Hi @gmbecker, @anajens 

How feasible would be to improve numerical output alignment in a cell? For example

```
df <- data.frame(
  USUBJID = as.character(c(1:15, 1)),
  ARM = factor(c("A", "B", "B", "A", "A", "A", "B", "A", "B", "B", "B", "B", "B", "B", "B", "B"), 
               levels = c("A", "B")),
  AETOXGR = factor(c(1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 1, 2, 5, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4, 4), levels = c(1:5)),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

basic_table() %>%
  split_cols_by("ARM") %>%
  summarize_occurrences_by_grade(var = "AETOXGR") %>%
  build_table(df)

       A          B    
-----------------------
1   2 (40%)   1 (9.1%) 
2      0      2 (18.2%)
3   1 (20%)       0    
4   1 (20%)   8 (72.7%)
5   1 (20%)       0  
```

It think this below formatting would be more nicer (note the alignment to the . for the percentage:

```
       A          B    
-----------------------
1   2 (40%)   1 ( 9.1%) 
2   0         2 (18.2%)
3   1 (20%)   0    
4   1 (20%)   8 (72.7%)
5   1 (20%)   0  
```

In other words, the numbers should be aligned according to their significance digits, i.e.
```
120
 22
 30
```

title: Crash with rxSolve() attempt of simulation
body:
Related to #548 (in that I'm still trying to make that simulation), the below code crashes R at the `rxSolve()` call:

```r
library(nlmixr)

linear_twocmt_iiv_growth <- function() {
  ini({
    tcl <- fixed(log(0.01)) ; label("Clearance (L/kg/hr)")
    tq <- fixed(log(0.05)) ; label("Intercompartmental clearance (L/kg/hr)")
    tv <- fixed(log(1.5)) ; label("Volume central (L/kg)")
    tv1 <- fixed(log(2)) ; label("Volume peripheral (L/kg)")
    
    tktr <- log(c(0.00001, 0.03, 3)) ; label("Transit compartment rate (1/hr)")
    slope <- c(-2, -0.02, 2) ; label("Slope on growth rate ((ng/mL)/hr)")
    ltumorgrowth <- log(c(0.0001, 0.01, 1)) ; label("Baseline tumor exponential growth rate (1/hr)")

    iiv_tumorgrowth ~ 0.1 ; label("Inter-individual variability in baseline tumor exponential growth rate")

    prop_sd <- 0.2 ; label("Proportional error for tumor volume (fraction)")
    add_sd <- 100 ; label("Additive error for tumor volume (mm^3)")
  })
  drake::no_deps(model({
    cl <- exp(tcl)
    q <- exp(tq)
    v <- exp(tv)
    v1 <- exp(tv1)
    kcp <- q/v
    kpc <- q/v1
    ktr <- exp(tktr)
    TUMOR(0) <- TUMORBL
    
    d/dt(CENTRAL) = -cl/v * CENTRAL - kcp*CENTRAL + kpc*PERIPH1
    d/dt(PERIPH1) = kcp*CENTRAL - kpc*PERIPH1
    # unit conversion
    cp <- CENTRAL/v*1000
    d/dt(TRANSIT) = ktr*(cp - TRANSIT)
    tumorgrowth <- exp(ltumorgrowth + iiv_tumorgrowth)
    ktumor <- tumorgrowth + slope*TRANSIT
    d/dt(TUMOR) = ktumor*TUMOR
    TUMOR ~ add(add_sd) + prop(prop_sd)
  }))
}

sim_dose <-
  data.frame(
    ID=1:50,
    time=0,
    amt=rep(seq(0, 20, by=5), each=10),
    evid=1,
    cmt="CENTRAL",
    mdv=1,
    TUMORBL=100
  )

sim_obs <-
  expand.grid(
    ID=1:50,
    time=(0:60)*24,
    amt=0,
    evid=0,
    cmt="TUMOR",
    mdv=0,
    TUMORBL=100
  )

sim_data <- rbind(sim_dose, sim_obs)
sim_data <- sim_data[order(sim_data$ID, sim_data$time), ]

model <- nlmixr(linear_twocmt_iiv_growth)
simulation <- rxSolve(model, events=sim_data)
```

title: Feature Request: Allow rxSolve to take in an un-solved nlmixr function definition
body:
Related to #548 in that I'm still trying to make that simulation...

It would be helpful if rxSolve could allow the object to be an nlmixr function definition (i.e. a function with an `ini()` and `model()`).

An example of the desired functionality is below.  If that is out of scope, a clearer error message would help rather than "`rxSolveSEXP(object, .ctl, .nms, .xtra, params, events, inits, : Not compatible with STRSXP: [type=NULL].`"

``` r
library(nlmixr)

linear_twocmt_iiv_growth <- function() {
  ini({
    tcl <- fixed(log(0.01)) ; label("Clearance (L/kg/hr)")
    tq <- fixed(log(0.05)) ; label("Intercompartmental clearance (L/kg/hr)")
    tv <- fixed(log(1.5)) ; label("Volume central (L/kg)")
    tv1 <- fixed(log(2)) ; label("Volume peripheral (L/kg)")
    
    tktr <- log(c(0.00001, 0.03, 3)) ; label("Transit compartment rate (1/hr)")
    slope <- c(-2, -0.02, 2) ; label("Slope on growth rate ((ng/mL)/hr)")
    ltumorgrowth <- log(c(0.0001, 0.01, 1)) ; label("Baseline tumor exponential growth rate (1/hr)")

    iiv_tumorgrowth ~ 0.1 ; label("Inter-individual variability in baseline tumor exponential growth rate")

    prop_sd <- 0.2 ; label("Proportional error for tumor volume (fraction)")
    add_sd <- 100 ; label("Additive error for tumor volume (mm^3)")
  })
  drake::no_deps(model({
    cl <- exp(tcl)
    q <- exp(tq)
    v <- exp(tv)
    v1 <- exp(tv1)
    kcp <- q/v
    kpc <- q/v1
    ktr <- exp(tktr)
    TUMOR(0) <- TUMORBL
    
    d/dt(CENTRAL) = -cl/v * CENTRAL - kcp*CENTRAL + kpc*PERIPH1
    d/dt(PERIPH1) = kcp*CENTRAL - kpc*PERIPH1
    # unit conversion
    cp <- CENTRAL/v*1000
    d/dt(TRANSIT) = ktr*(cp - TRANSIT)
    tumorgrowth <- exp(ltumorgrowth + iiv_tumorgrowth)
    ktumor <- tumorgrowth + slope*TRANSIT
    d/dt(TUMOR) = ktumor*TUMOR
    TUMOR ~ add(add_sd) + prop(prop_sd)
  }))
}

sim_dose <-
  data.frame(
    ID=1:50,
    time=0,
    amt=rep(seq(0, 20, by=5), each=10),
    evid=1,
    cmt="CENTRAL",
    mdv=1,
    TUMORBL=100
  )

sim_obs <-
  expand.grid(
    ID=1:50,
    time=(0:60)*24,
    amt=0,
    evid=0,
    cmt="TUMOR",
    mdv=0,
    TUMORBL=100
  )

sim_data <- rbind(sim_dose, sim_obs)
sim_data <- sim_data[order(sim_data$ID, sim_data$time), ]

simulation <- rxSolve(linear_twocmt_iiv_growth, events=sim_data)
#> Error in rxSolveSEXP(object, .ctl, .nms, .xtra, params, events, inits, : Not compatible with STRSXP: [type=NULL].
```

<sup>Created on 2021-07-26 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.0)</sup>

title: ED50 using ML & AIC: Phoenix NLME and PROC NLMIXED
body:
Hi,

I am very fresh to the r so please excuse my limitations for nlmixr and r.

My Interest is to calculate ED50 and Emax of dose response study (skin blanching) using ML and AIC criteria.

I have prepared SAS code using PROC NLMIXED for Emax and ED50 and results are matching with phoenix NMLE -Emax modeling.

Now I wanted to develop the code with r using nlmixr and need help from the experts.
Below is model text for NLME
test(){
	covariate(C)
	E = Emax * C / (EC50 + C)
	error(EEps = 1)
	observe(EObs(C) = E + EEps)
	stparm(EC50 = tvEC50)
	stparm(Emax = tvEmax + nEmax)
	fixef(tvEC50 = c(, 1, ))
	fixef(tvEmax = c(, 1, ))
	ranef(diag(nEmax) = c(1))
}

Please find data which were used for the calculation and result for Emax and ED50 were -6.4 and 52.5 .

Can anyone help me to build r code using nlmixr

[AUEC.zip](https://github.com/nlmixrdevelopment/nlmixr/files/6884707/AUEC.zip)

author: jcubic

title: Should I turn foceiControl(transitAbs) to "FALSE" if I hardcode it into the ODE?
body:
Hi Matthew, 

May I check if I need to turn the `foceiControl(transAbs=FALSE)` if I hardcode the transit absorption compartment to the model. 

The model code I use is shown below: 

```{r} 
iteration_17 <- function(){
  ini({
    
    tktr <- log(6)   
    tn   <- log(0.9)     
    tka  <- log(0.35)   
    tcl  <- log(60)   
    tv2  <- log(95)   
    feff <- -0.4   
    ncov <- -0.3
    
    eta.ka ~ 0.1
    eta.cl+eta.v2~c(1,
                    0.1,1)
    
    add.err  <- 0.01
    prop.err <- 0.1
  })
  
  model({
    
    ktr <- exp(tktr)     
    n   <- exp(tn)                       
    ka  <- exp(tka + eta.ka + (ncov*FOOD))
    cl  <- exp(tcl + eta.cl)
    v2  <- exp(tv2 + eta.v2)
    f   <- 1 + feff*FOOD 
    
    Dose  = 250         # all subjects received 250mg
    lnfac = log(2.5066) + (n + 0.5)*log(n) - n 
    
    d/dt(depot)  = exp(log(f*Dose) + log(ktr) + n*log(ktr*t) - ktr*t - lnfac) - ka*depot 
    d/dt(center) = ka*depot - cl/v2*center 
 
    cp           = center/v2 
    cp           ~ prop(prop.err) + add(add.err)
  })
}

fit.iteration_17 <- nlmixr(iteration_17, data = met.merged3, est = "focei",
                               table = tableControl(cwres = TRUE, npde = TRUE), foceiControl(transitAbs = FALSE))

```
Thank you very much. Any feedback on this matter is much appreciated.
author: WenYao-Mak

title: Toggle tooltips throw error when hovering over plot
body:
When you enable tooltips and then on the same plot you disable them it doesn't remove the event for proximity and mousemove and it tries to calculate distance when it has no optimization data stored in each point. and throw an error.

The solution is to check if points have data saved before processing.

title: Possible bug in how align_plots() works?
body:
#### Issue description

While writing tests for it, I could never cover or trigger a certain part of the function. Generally, parts of the function don't seem very robust. I assume there is a functional bug and not all lines are actually used to achieve what it currently does.

1) The function obviously works
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12818242/127642358-2d67787a-cf1f-4bd3-b36a-49aa62dd63dc.png)

2) Lines 52-55 seem to be untriggerable?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12818242/127642444-1dc2d591-7b79-40d7-8bcf-4010ca21b278.png)

Based on my testing it seems that lines 36-38 and 44-47 do what they're supposed to. That way, 49-58 defaults to x, never jumping into the if-condition. In my tests, `legends.widths` only ever returned `NULL`, even when properly aligning the widths. Therefore, `max.legends.width` defaults to `-Inf`. It seems this behaviour doesn't keep the code from working though. 

Also, the function could be written in a more maintenance-friendly way, e.g. [line 38](https://github.com/openpharma/visR/blob/a8e790e29fc6f2448bc7daed955c6de63a2805cd/R/utils_visr.R#L54).

title: rtables::var_labels throws an error instead of an empty string for an empty data.frame
body:
According to the doc string of rtables::var_labels rtables::var_labels returns a named character vector with the variable labels (empty string if not specified), but it returns an error if passed an empty data.frame(). I would expect it to return a character vector of length 0 because an empty data.frame is a valid data.frame with 0 columns and has no variable labels specified.
```r
rtables::var_labels(data.frame()) # throws an error
```

title: create a function to test all packages
body:
We would like to create a CI pipeline that installs and tests all packages  in the staged dependencies and run a matrix test over different environments.

Please create a `test_all(entrypoints = "<github_repo>", branch = "main")` (or similar named) function that runs:

```
R CMD build
R CMD check
R CMD INSTALL
```

sequence on all packages in the staged dependencies. Note by default external dependencies should not be installed as we expect they are already available in the environment.

@dinakar29 please add further requirements to create an action.


# Note

Please pay attention of artifacts created that we can then use in in a dashboard.

Artifacts are:
-  `<pkgname>.Rcheck/00check.log`
 - `<pkgname>.Rcheck/<pkgname>-Ex.Rout`
 - install log
 - build log

for each package

library(rtables)

title: Guess filetype for files without extensions
body:
When evaluating file specifications to create file collections, we should follow this:

- If a file has a known extensions, mark it as text or binary based on the dictionary (implemented)
- Include files that do not have a file extension, and files with extensions not covered by the dictionary
    - Guess if the file is (canonically) text, otherwise mark them as binary
        -  I'd prefer zlib's algorithm: https://github.com/madler/zlib/blob/master/doc/txtvsbin.txt
        - If a file does not have any content, then mark it as binary
- Document this flow in the specification section

Please briefly describe your problem and, when relevant, the output you expect.

If at all possible, please include a [minimal, reproducible
example](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5963269/how-to-make-a-great-r-reproducible-example).
The `rtables` team will be much more likely to resolve your issue if they are

Please delete this preamble after you have read it.

---

your brief description of the problem

```r
library(rtables)

# your reproducible example here

```

where fit.s is the same as the example  in https://nlmixrdevelopment.github.io/nlmixr/articles/broom.html
i.e.,

Other functions like

When running the same code on another computer broom.mixed works fine. Versions for broom.mixed and nlmixr are 0.2.7 and 2.0.4. Any ideas on how to troubleshoot this?

Initially reported by @kieranjmartin on Feb 26, 2020 (for initial version of `rtables`)

> 1. Good methods to glue together tables vertically and horizontally
> 2. Ways to handle programmatic inputs, clearly documented (things like rrowl)
> 3. Methods to convert data frames (and other typical objects) into rtables
> 4. Accessor methods for modifying rtables simply

> 6. More control over alignment
> 7. Much more sophistication in as_html(), and the ability to modify the html object both before and after without actively rewriting the html code
author: anajens

title: How to construct a multi col header
body:
Issue originally reported by @kieranjmartin

> I know you are encouraged to use the in built arguments to construct a table, but if I wanted to construct a table manually I'm not quite clear on how to do this.
> 
> This works
> 
```
rtable(rheader(rrow(row.name = NULL, rcell("all obs", colspan = 4)), 
               rrow(NULL, "a", "b", "c", "d")),
       rrow("range", 10, 20, 10, 20),
       rrow("number", rcell(20, colspan = 4)))
```

>But this doesn't

```
rtable(rheader(rrow(row.name = NULL, rcell("all obs", colspan = 4))),
       rrow("range", 10, 20, 10, 20),
       rrow("number", rcell(20, colspan = 4)))
```

> The reason seems to be that rheader is collapsing down to one column there, even if it shouldn't. Is there a way to accomplish the latter scenario? Putting a dummy empty row doesn't work either

```
rtable(rheader(rrow(row.name = NULL, rcell("all obs", colspan = 4)), 
              rrow(NULL, "", "", "", "")),
      rrow("range", 10, 20, 10, 20),
      rrow("number", rcell(20, colspan = 4)))
errors.
```

>Also, this actually only errors when you print the object; you can actually create the object, it just won't print successfully, with message
> 
> Error in rbind(header_content$span, body_spans) :
> number of columns of matrices must match (see arg 2)
> 
> This is in version 0.3.8
author: anajens

title: Improve printing of rtables
body:
Issue originally reported by @thomas-neitmann on Jul 15, 2020:

>The current printing of an rtable with the dashed line underneath the header looks rather poor.

```
                            A: Drug X             B: Placebo          C: Combination
                             (N=134)               (N=134)               (N=132)    
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Age
  n                            134                   134                   132      
```

>STREAM uses underscores above and below the header as well as after the last line. This is visually much more appealing. Implementing this in rtable.toString() should be fairly easy.


```
____________________________________________________________________________________

                            A: Drug X             B: Placebo          C: Combination
                             (N=134)               (N=134)               (N=132)    
____________________________________________________________________________________

Age
  n                            134                   134                   132      

```

title: direction = `c("upstream", "downstream")` is confusing

Currently:

- _upstream_ repos in package's dep tree
- _downstream_ repos which have package in their dep tree
- _c(upstream, downstream)_ all repos being co-developed

Proposal:
- _upstream_ repos in package's dep tree
- _downstream_ repos which have package in their dep tree

title: Major refactor
body:
Note @dinakar29 **This PR changes some of the exported function interfaces so any github workflows relying on these need to be changed at the same time as this is merged**




Closes #72 and #54 (see https://github.com/openpharma/staged.dependencies/pull/88#issue-720419742 for #54)

- This PR refactors large parts of the package although the functionality of the addins remains unchanged.

There is now an S3 object `dependency_structure` created using function `dependency_table` (see the function doc for more information) which can be used as below. There have also been simplifications to the structure of the code base

- Using the `project_type` argument you can create a `dependency_structure` from a remote repo rather than checking it out first and passing in a directory.

```
# create dependency_structure object from a checked out repo...
x <- dependency_table(project = "../stageddeps.electricity", verbose = 1)
# ... or directly from a remote 
x <- dependency_table(project = "openpharma/stageddeps.electricity@https://github.com", 
                      project_type = "repo@host", 
                      feature = "main", 
                      verbose = 1)

# print and plot it
print(x)
if (require("visNetwork")) plot(x)

#install upstream dependencies
install_deps(x, verbose = 1)

# check downstream packages
check_downstream(x, verbose = 1, check_args = c("--no-manual"))
```

- A large number of tests have been added - there are open issues for further tests.

- Bumped the version to 0.2 due to the scale of changes here
author: nikolas-burkoff

author: elong0527

title: The Font size doesn't consistency between function default value and the Arguments description
body:
Take an example: [rtf_page_header](https://merck.github.io/r2rtf/reference/rtf_page_header.html)

```
rtf_page_header(
  tbl,
  text = "Page \\pagenumber of \\pagefield",
  text_font = 1,
  text_format = NULL,
  text_font_size = 12,
  text_color = NULL,
  text_background_color = NULL,
  text_justification = "r",
  text_indent_first = 0,
  text_indent_left = 0,
  text_indent_right = 0,
  text_space = 1,
  text_space_before = 15,
  text_space_after = 15,
  text_convert = TRUE
)
```

The text font size in function default value is 12, while in Arguments description is 9. This in-consistence occurred in other functions, too.

<html>
<body>
<!--StartFragment-->

text_font_size | Text font size. Default is 9. To vary text font size by column, use numeric vector with length of vector equal to number of columns displayed e.g. c(9,20,40).
-- | --


<!--EndFragment-->
</body>
</html>
author: DawnYe

title: trim_levels_to_map vs trim_levels_in_group
body:
Hi @gmbecker, 

I'm curious to hear your thoughts on the relationship between `trim_levels_to_map` vs `trim_levels_in_group`. 

Is the plan to retire `trim_levels_in_group` altogether? 

If not, then I think `trim_levels_in_group` could be useful in simple cases where the user wants to control levels of a variable passed down to `analyze` but without specifying a map. I'm thinking `trim_levels_in_group` could be a type of "super drop_split_levels" function similar to `drop_and_remove_levels`. The limitation right now is that it just controls `innervar` levels and not the levels of the split variable itself which I think would be common.

Here's an example use case: If I want to achieve the layout below...

```
      all obs
-------------
A            
  a      1   
B            
  b      1   
C            
  c      1  
```

... I can use these layouts:
```r
dat1 <- data.frame(
  l1 = factor(c("A", "B", "C"), levels = c("A", "B", "C")), # note that level X is not included
  l2 = factor(c("a", "b", "c"), levels = c("a", "b", "c", "x"))
)

# This works
basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("l1", split_fun = trim_levels_in_group("l2")) %>%
  analyze("l2") %>%
  build_table(dat1)

dat2 <- data.frame(
  l1 = factor(c("A", "B", "C"), levels = c("A", "B", "C", "X")), # here we add X to "l1"
  l2 = factor(c("a", "b", "c"), levels = c("a", "b", "c", "x"))
)

# This gives an error because trim_levels_in_group does not drop the empty "l1" levels
basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("l1", split_fun = trim_levels_in_group("l2")) %>%
  analyze("l2") %>%
  build_table(dat2)

map <- data.frame(lapply(dat2, as.character), stringsAsFactors = FALSE)

# This works nicely but user needs to do the extra step and provide a map
basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("l1", split_fun = trim_levels_to_map(map)) %>%
  analyze("l2") %>%
  build_table(dat2)

```

title: add handler for test code headers

add option to pass header values to markdown rendered from test code files via the test code name. include ability of user to pass a vector of headers when calling `vt_file`.

vt_file(path, dynamic_referencing) # headers are pulled from test_that "desc" argument

- Option 2: user specified
```
tc_files <- c(file1, file2, ...)

```

title: riskmetric is archived on CRAN
body:
I wanted to look at the package but I found it is no longer on [CRAN](https://cran.r-project.org/package=riskmetric):

> Package ‘riskmetric’ was removed from the CRAN repository.
> 
> Formerly available versions can be obtained from the [archive](https://cran.r-project.org/src/contrib/Archive/riskmetric).
> 
> Archived on 2021-08-17 as repeated check problems were not corrected in time.
> 
> A summary of the most recent check results can be obtained from the [check results archive](https://cran-archive.r-project.org/web/checks/2021/2021-08-17_check_results_riskmetric.html).
> 
> Please use the canonical form [https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=riskmetric](https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=riskmetric) to link to this page.
> 

The only check I found failing is on r-devel-fedora-gcc (copying it here as I don't know how long these checks archives stay):

<details>
<summary>Check Details</summary>

> Version: 0.1.1
> Check: tests
> Result: ERROR
>      Running ‘testthat.R’ [150s/168s]
>     Running the tests in ‘tests/testthat.R’ failed.
>     Complete output:
>      > library(testthat)
>      > library(riskmetric)
>      >
>      > options(repos = "fake-cran.fake-r-project.org")
>      >
>      > test_check("riskmetric")
>      ══ Skipped tests ═══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
>      • snapshots appear to be failing due to random order of pkg_ref fields (3)
>     
>      ══ Failed tests ════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════
>      ── Failure (test_pkg_ref.R:31:3): pkg_ref infers source when not explicitly provided ──
>      `ref3` has class 'pkg_install'/'pkg_ref'/'environment', not 'pkg_bioc_remote'/'pkg_remote'/'pkg_ref'/'environment'.
>      ── Failure (test_pkg_ref.R:32:3): pkg_ref infers source when not explicitly provided ──
>      ref3$source (`actual`) not equal to "pkg_bioc_remote" (`expected`).
>     
>      `actual`: "pkg_install"
>      `expected`: "pkg_bioc_remote"
>     
>      [ FAIL 2 | WARN 0 | SKIP 3 | PASS 45 ]
>      Error: Test failures
>      Execution halted
> Flavor: r-devel-linux-x86_64-fedora-gcc

</details>

Not sure if you were aware, but is there a plan to submit the package to CRAN again?
Edit: I just realize that there was a [recent release](https://github.com/pharmaR/riskmetric/pull/217) on 2021-07-29, which doesn't seem to have fixed all the errors.

title: Dev/cohort
body:
This the start of a cohort-level analysis of risk. This is a very rough draft, but I am hoping it will seed a number of discussions on how we implement a cohort class, how we dispatch methods to it, what a cohort metric is and is not.

To do: 
1. More robust cohort_ref constructors
  1. should be able to handle different types of libraries (installed, remote, etc)
  2. should make assessment of the cohort against the library easy to implement (right now it is a bit convoluted and ugly)
  3. Maybe add a meta/aggregate ref slot for the library
2. Better defintions of what goes into the `ref` object vs `assessment` object
3. A more formal cohort assessment class structure; currently just using a list
4. methods to handle the case where library is `NULL` to do a cohort comparison against itself.

author: aehmann-gsk

title: Allow system dependencies to be installed
body:
Should install system dependencies of external (and internal) dependencies
Should be platform independent (or if not possible then should handle gracefully) 

What happens if you don't have permission to install the dependencies? etc

Should we actually install or should we have a function `get_external_dependencies(dep_structure, <<args>>)`
and then it is user's responsibility to actually install them? e.g. in an automation pipeline have:

```
x <- dependency_table(...)
external_deps <- get_external_dependencies(x, ...)
if (length(external_deps) > 0) {
  # run external_deps installation command
)
install_deps(x, ...) # install R packages
```

This would be a much cleaner solution rather than as a side effect of running install_deps having lots of system deps installed
but may not be as easy to use or implement...

author: elong0527

title: nested .ungroup_stats in make_afun
body:
Hi @gmbecker ,

I'm wondering if `make_afun` can work with nested statistics and preserve the label groups? Here's a simple example:


```
> s_grp <- function(df, a = 1, b = 2) {
+   
+   list(
+     letters = list(
+       A = list(a1 = a, a2 = a*2),
+       B = list(b1 = b, b2 = b*2, b3 = b*3)
+     )
+   )
+   
+ }
> 
> s_grp(iris)
$letters
$letters$A
$letters$A$a1
[1] 1

$letters$A$a2
[1] 2


$letters$B
$letters$B$b1
[1] 2

$letters$B$b2
[1] 4

$letters$B$b3
[1] 6

> a_grp <- make_afun(s_grp, .ungroup_stats ="letters")
> 
> a_grp(iris)
RowsVerticalSection (in_rows) object print method:
----------------------------
  row_name formatted_cell indent_mod row_label
1        A           1, 2          0         A
2        B        2, 4, 6          0         B
```

Ideal output in the layout at would look like this (this is without any split functions being applied):
```
A
  a1 1
  a2 2
B
  b1 2
  b2 4
  b3 6
```

x <- dependency_table("openpharma/stageddeps.electricity", project_type = "repo@host", feature = "main")

author: nikolas-burkoff

title: Implement `derive_param_tte` function
body:
Implement a function to derive a time-to-event parameter:
```
derive_param_tte(
  start_date = TRTSDTM,
  event_conditions = list(
    tte_cond(
     dataset = adrs,
     filter = PARAMCD == “BOR” & AVALC == "PD",
     date = ADT,
     set_values_to = vars(
       EVENTDESC = “PROGRESSION”,
       SRCDOM = “ADRS”,
       SRCVAR = “ADT”
     ),
    tte_cond(
     dataset = adsl,
     filter = DTHFL == “Y”,
     date = DTHDT,
     set_values_to = vars(
       EVENTDESC = “DEATH”,
       SRCDOM = “ADSL”,
       SRCVAR = “DTHDT”
     )
   ),
  censor_condition = list(
    tte_cond(
      dataset = adsl,
      date = LSTALVDT
      censor = 1
      set_values_to = vars(
         EVENTDESC = “LAST KNOWN ALIVE DATE”,
         SRCDOM = “ADSL”,
         SRCVAR = “LSTALVDT”
       )
     )
   ),
  set_values_to = vars(PARAMCD = “PFS”,PARAM = “Progression Free Survival”)
)
```
`ADT` is set to the first of the event dates. If there is no event, it is set to the last of the censoring dates.

author: timtreis

title: Allow staged.deps to work on gitlab CI
body:
When working on gitlab automation the code that is checked out is a detached HEAD not the current state of the branch and therefore although you can specify `feature = <<branch name>>` we have this check:

```
# check that locally checked out branch is consistent with branch rule
  available_branches <- names(git2r::branches(repo_dir, flags = "local"))
  branch <- select_branch_rule(available_branches)
  stopifnot(branch %in% available_branches)
  if (branch != get_current_branch(repo_dir)) {
    stop("You must check out branch ", branch, " for repository in directory ", repo_dir,
         ", currently ", get_current_branch(repo_dir), " is checked out.")
  }
```

author: timtreis

title: Stratifier inside of tableone call leads to NAs, should be automatically removed
body:
#### Issue description

A naive 'tableone()` call leads to NAs being introduced into the rendered table.

```
tableone(data, strata = "Sex", 
         title = TITLE, datasource = DATASOURCE)
```
![Screenshot_20210910_112934](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12818242/132832837-019601a6-15c5-486e-8183-6d0ff1c72b12.png)

Therefore the strata needs to be manually removed before rendering the table.

```
get_tableone(data, strata = "Sex") %>% 
  filter(variable != "Sex") %>% 
  render(title = TITLE, datasource = DATASOURCE)
```

This should be done automatically.

Can we look into this?

title: Minor bug when summarizing risk metric scores
body:
With riskmetric v0.1.1, I'm getting the following error when I try to get the risk metric scores for one package:
`res <- pkg_ref(c("MatchIt")) %>%
     pkg_assess() %>%
     pkg_score() %>%
     dplyr::mutate(risk = riskmetric::summarize_scores(.))`
`Error in UseMethod("mutate") : 
  no applicable method for 'mutate' applied to an object of class "list"`

But when I add an additional package, the error is resolved and I'm able to get the summary scores:
`res <- pkg_ref(c("MatchIt", "ggplot2")) %>%
     pkg_assess() %>%
     pkg_score() %>%
     dplyr::mutate(risk = riskmetric::summarize_scores(.))`

author: nikolas-burkoff

title: trim_levels_by_map - force to not show certain records from analysis function
body:
Hallo @gmbecker (@anajens , @waddella - FYI)

Consider the following case with new `trim_levels_to_map` function:

```
df_3 <- data.frame(
  LBCAT = factor(c("CHEMISTRY", "CHEMISTRY", "CHEMISTRY", "IMMUNOLOGY"), levels = c("CHEMISTRY", "IMMUNOLOGY")),
  PARAMCD = factor(c("ALT", "CRP", "CRP", "IGA"), levels = c("ALT", "CRP", "IGA")),
  ANRIND = factor(c("LOW", "LOW", "HIGH", "HIGH"), levels = c("LOW", "HIGH"))
)

map_3 <- data.frame(
  LBCAT = c("CHEMISTRY", "CHEMISTRY", "CHEMISTRY", "IMMUNOLOGY"),
  PARAMCD = c("ALT", "CRP", "CRP", "IGA"),
  ANRIND = c("LOW", "LOW", "HIGH", "HIGH")
)

lyt <- basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("LBCAT") %>%
  split_rows_by("PARAMCD", split_fun = trim_levels_to_map(map = map_3)) %>%
  analyze("ANRIND")

build_table(lyt, df_3)

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  ALT               
    LOW         1   
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
    HIGH        1   
IMMUNOLOGY          
  IGA               
    HIGH        1   
```

Now, say we have incomplete data, referred here to as A, B, C cases:

```
### CASE A

df_3a <- df_3[-1, ]
build_table(lyt, df_3a)

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  ALT               
    LOW         0   
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
    HIGH        1   
IMMUNOLOGY          
  IGA               
    HIGH        1 

### CASE B

df_3b <- df_3[-3, ]
build_table(lyt, df_3b)

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  ALT               
    LOW         1   
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
    HIGH        0   
IMMUNOLOGY          
  IGA               
    HIGH        1  

### CASE C

df_3c <- df_3[-4, ]
build_table(lyt, df_3c)

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  ALT               
    LOW         1   
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
    HIGH        1   
IMMUNOLOGY          
  IGA               
    HIGH        0   

```

Apart from the above, we would also like to be able to produce the following output for cases A, B, C, i.e. the output without "0" stats records:

```
### CASE A

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
    HIGH        1   
IMMUNOLOGY          
  IGA               
    HIGH        1 


### CASE B

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  ALT               
    LOW         1   
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
IMMUNOLOGY          
  IGA               
    HIGH        1  


### CASE C

             all obs
--------------------
CHEMISTRY           
  ALT               
    LOW         1   
  CRP               
    LOW         1   
    HIGH        1   

```
I think, that it should be partially handled with the analysis function (with e.g. `drop` logical parametr). 
The question is then, what should analysis function return so that the rtables routines can understand it is as "do not print"?
Note that for a couple of good reasons we do not want to modify the `map` itself just to handle this "0" record case.

Thank you
Wojtek

author: rebecca-albrecht

title: `visR::add_risktable()` fails with a cryptic error message when the `strata` variable contains missing values.
body:
#### Issue description

When generating a Kaplan-Meier plot with a stratifying variable, `visR::add_risktable()` fails with a rather cryptic error message. If one does not include the risk table, the plot is generated without problems. It is only the creating of the risk table that produces the error, as illustrated in the example below

#### Steps to reproduce the issue

Please share code if possible.

```r
library(visR)
set.seed(42)

# Dataset without missing values
dataset <- data.frame(
  AVAL = rexp(n = 30, rate = 10),
  CNSR = sample(c(0, 1), size = 30, replace = TRUE),
  strata = gl(n = 2, k = 15, labels = c("A", "B"))
)

# Dataset with missing values
dataset_na <- dataset
is.na(dataset_na$strata[sample(seq_len(30), size = 5)]) <- TRUE

# Works
dataset %>%
  visR::estimate_KM(strata = "strata") %>%
  visR::visr(fun = "surv") %>%
  visR::add_risktable(label = c("Subjects at Risk", "Censored"),
                      statlist = c("n.risk", "n.censor"))

# Fails
dataset_na %>%
  visR::estimate_KM(strata = "strata") %>%
  visR::visr(fun = "surv") %>%
  visR::add_risktable(label = c("Subjects at Risk", "Censored"),
                      statlist = c("n.risk", "n.censor"))
```

#### What's the expected result?

We would expect the risk table to be added to the plot.


#### What's the actual result?

The following error message is produced:

```
Error: Tibble columns must have compatible sizes.
* Size 5: Column `na.action`.
* Size 25: Columns `time`, `n.risk`, `n.event`, `n.censor`, `surv`, and 9 more.
ℹ Only values of size one are recycled.
Run `rlang::last_error()` to see where the error occurred.
```

#### Additional details / screenshot

The issue is localised in the `tidyme.R` file, and more precisely starting from [this line](https://github.com/openpharma/visR/blob/a70cc2d775f7510dd1f03edf77cac2421943063a/R/tidyme.R#L66). The missing values cause the objects that should be bound together to have different lengths, and this is what seems to be igniting the issue.

author: mdshw5

title: `riskmetric` service discussion (from 2021/09/15)
body:
At our sprint meeting on 2021/09/15, we were joined by @mpadge who walked us through some considerations rOpenSci has had when trying to do similar reporting.

I tried my best to keep minutes:

> Mark described an rOpenSci workflow that includes
>   - running pre-review checks
>   - adding a markdown-formatted report to the merge request comment thread including check results
> 
> On the decision to use an API service vs GitHub Action
>   - API is easier to debug locally
>   - An action is easier to manage environment (offload responsibility of system libraries to users of the Action)
>   - As discussed, the management of an environment would present a major challenge - GitHub Actions might be a better choice for our use case
>  
> On producing a badge
>   - rOpenSci has an example of how they manage this in [ropensci-org/badges](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/merge_requests.html#get-single-mr)
>  - recommendation is to get the rest of the workflow working first, then add in a badge - but hosting a badge on a registry should be a last step in building out the service
> 
> On hosting a `riskmetric` reports portal
>   - rOpenSci has a clever process for submitting package-produced html pages to a repository whose github pages page collects and serves these pages as a report portal
>   - rOpenSci has an example of how [they serve `pkgstats` reports](https://github.com/ropensci-review-tools/roreviewapi/tree/gh-pages), with the code for managing deployment in [gh-pages.R](https://github.com/ropensci-review-tools/roreviewapi/blob/main/R/gh-pages.R)
>  - The action can share a link to this report (I missed noting down how this link is shared to a user) as a more user-friendly mechanism of sharing check results
>  - Mark walked us through how credentials are managed to allow individual package repositories to push new static pages into this pages-hosted webpage, but it went over my head. We have a lot of work to do until this is a necessary part of our process - we can revisit it when we're ready to start hosting pages.
> 

---

tagging @mpadge @daroczig

title: get_pvalue gives too many digits
body:
#### Issue description



#### Steps to reproduce the issue

As pointed out during Charlottas talk at PSI2021, the `get_pvalue()` function doesn't round the Chisq values by default. This should have a default precision

```r
library(visR)

adtte %>%
  estimate_KM("SEX") %>%
  get_pvalue()

#   Equality across strata      Chisq        df        p-value
#   Log-Rank                    3.739420     1           0.053
#   Wilcoxon                    4.603920     1           0.032
#   Tarone-Ware                 4.643328     1           0.031

```

#### What's the expected result?

Same precision as for p-value

author: nikolas-burkoff

title: Life table
body:
## Idea

As discussed during PSI2021, life tables might be a thing that we should implement. It seems like a fairly quick win and would be an additional feature integrating into the time-to-event-analysis theme.

**Do you have any examples you can share of what it looks like?**

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_table

```
visR::adtte %>%
  visR::estimate_KM() %>%
  visR::get_risktable(statlist = c("n.risk", "n.event", "n.censor")) %>%
  tidyr::spread(y_values, Overall) %>%
  visR::render(title = "Life table", datasource = "visR::adtte")
```

![david_output](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12818242/134705770-6b000189-394f-4049-9f9b-83aa04b6b9da.png)

**What potential packages/functions could be used to make this plot?**

Farily easy with `tidyr` and `visR`, merely a wrapper around a bunch of stuff that's already implemented. Would be nice to have some standard intervals on the left (regularily spaced, smart guessing?) but to also expose the option of custom intervals like

```
visR::adtte %>%
  visR::estimate_KM() %>%
  visR::lifetable(intervals = list(c(-Inf, 18), c(19-60), c(61, Inf)),
                  columns = c("n.risk", "n.event", "n.censor", "survival", "CI_lower", "CI_upper"))
```

title: "subscript out of bounds" during SAEM model setup
body:
I'm working to generate a reprex for this, but as usual the data and model are proprietary

I have a moderate-complexity model that gets a "subscript out of bounds" error in `nlmixrUI.saem.model.omega()` due to the fact that `etd` goes up to 18 but `dm` is only 17.  So, the matrix dimension is not big enough for the etas (if I'm reading the code correctly).

https://github.com/nlmixrdevelopment/nlmixr/blob/9fc906a82e27e7c74bc0b31cdfe741d87fe6fe7f/R/ui.R#L3153-L3162

One challenge with making a reprex is that when I use the same model but much simpler data, `obj$env$.bpars` in `nlmixrUI.saem.model.omega()` is NULL instead of having a function body.

This is with nlmixr 2.0.5, RxODE 1.1.1, lotri 0.3.1, and R 4.1.0.

author: SHAESEN2

title: htmltools suggestions
body:
It shouldn't ever be necessary to call do.call() on htmltools tag
functions, due to several little-known features:

1. `NULL` arguments are ignored
2. Children can be nested in lists, they'll be treated like they
   were passed directly
3. Multiple `class` arguments are automatically pasted together
   with a space in between

Also, it's not relevant for the current `as_html` implementation, but it's possible to use tidyeval semantics as well (e.g. for dynamic attribute names, you can use `div(!!attrib_name := attrib_value)`, or `div(!!!attribs)`).
