title: Replace some cell content by empty spaces.
body:
When creating a table using the `split_cols_by_multivar()` function, I would like to be able to replace the data highlighted in yellow in the "BASELINE" row and columns "CHANGE" by some empty spaces, since the magnitude of the change compared to baseline in the baseline row will always be null. *NB: the data presented here are randomly generated*

Thank you for your time.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/64274616/135067383-8922cbb8-c657-4131-a9f0-ebfc916a980a.png)
 *Further rows are omitted for conciseness* 


the code to generate the table is:
```r

lyt <- basic_table()  %>%
    split_cols_by("ACTARM") %>%
    split_rows_by(
      "PARAM",
      split_fun = drop_split_levels,
      label_pos = "hidden",
      split_label = "Parameter"
    ) %>%
    split_rows_by(
      "AVISIT",
      split_fun = drop_split_levels,
      label_pos = "hidden",
      split_label = "Analysis Visit"
    ) %>%
    split_cols_by_multivar(
      vars = c("AVAL", "CHG"),
      varlabels = c("Analysis", "Change"),
      nested = TRUE
    ) %>%
    summarize_colvars() %>%
    append_topleft("Parameter") %>%
    append_topleft(" Analysis Visit")


library(scda)
library(dplyr)
sd <- synthetic_cdisc_data("rcd_2021_03_22")
adlb <- sd$adlb %>%
mutate(ANL01FL = 'Y')

build_table(lyt, adlb)

```

author: BFalquet

title: Revert DESC file after installation
body:
Once we have installed a package from the cache we cannot then do anything else with it (i.e. if we install a downstream package and then try to check it)

```
library(staged.dependencies)
clear_cache()
x <- staged.dependencies::dependency_table("openpharma/stageddeps.water", "repo@host", ref = "main", verbose = FALSE)
# only install these 2 as need renv removed from stageddeps.electricity for others to work
install_deps(x, install_direction = c("upstream", "downstream"), 
  dependency_packages = c("stageddeps.water", "stageddeps.garden"))
# note check downstream also installs required deps as you can call this without having
# called install_deps first
check_downstream(x, downstream_packages = "stageddeps.garden")
```

See [here](https://github.com/openpharma/staged.dependencies/blob/7f24c2140e78b85ba3959eef33484ae2a802ce09/R/git_tools.R#L235)

author: koegerr

title: Suggest adding units to derive_agegr_*
body:
The `derive_agegr_*` functions assume `age_var` is provided in years, but upstream functions like `derive_vars_aage()` helpfully allow specification of units. Here's an example of a breaking `derive_agegr_fda()`, where the patient is 35 but gets assigned to the 65+ group because `AAGE` was created in months. Adding a `unit` arg to `derive_agegr_*` (with a default to "years") could remedy this. 

```
dat <- tibble::tribble(
  ~BRTHDT, ~RANDDT,
  lubridate::ymd("1984-09-06"), lubridate::ymd("2020-02-24")
)

# oops
dat %>%
  derive_vars_aage(unit = "months") %>%
  derive_agegr_fda(AAGE, AGEGR1)
```

```
# A tibble: 1 x 5
  BRTHDT     RANDDT      AAGE AAGEU  AGEGR1
  <date>     <date>     <dbl> <chr>  <fct> 
1 1984-09-06 2020-02-24   425 MONTHS >=65  
```

author: dgkf

title: When should row_paths include "root"?
body:
@gmbecker this example below is silly but it's just to illustrate some different layouts from `tern` where we need to know the row paths in order to use `label_at_path`. I mostly find ex (1) and (2) not very intuitive and I'd like to get your take on the rationale. 

```r
# Ex 1. No split function: row paths include root
t1 <- basic_table() %>%
  summarize_row_groups("ITTFL", label_fstr = "ALL")%>%
  build_table(ex_adsl)

# Ex 2. Add single split: row paths don't include root
t2 <- basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("ITTFL", split_fun = keep_split_levels("Y"), nested = FALSE) %>%
  summarize_row_groups("ITTFL")%>%
  build_table(ex_adsl)

# Ex 3. Add multiple (non-nested) splits: row paths include root again
t3 <- basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("ITTFL", split_fun = keep_split_levels("Y"), nested = FALSE) %>%
  summarize_row_groups("ITTFL")%>%
  split_rows_by("ITTFL", split_fun = keep_split_levels("Y"), nested = FALSE) %>%
  summarize_row_groups("ITTFL")%>%
  build_table(ex_adsl)
```

```
> row_paths(t1)
[[1]]
[1] "root"     "@content" "ALL"     

> row_paths(t2)
[[1]]
[1] "ITTFL"    "Y"        "@content" "Y"       

> row_paths(t3)
[[1]]
[1] "root"     "ITTFL"    "Y"        "@content" "Y"       

[[2]]
[1] "root"     "ITTFL"    "Y"        "@content" "Y"    
```
author: anajens

title: Can sorting be done to tables constructed via rbind?
body:
Hi @gmbecker , I'm trying to create a table in two parts and then sort the result which doesn't seem to work. See example below.

The reason for splitting the table in two is because the layout must be able to display content rows with 0s which doesn't work because `analyze` must always return some content. As an alternative I would use dummy levels and then prune them away but was curious to hear your thoughts on whether the rbind approach is even feasible.


```r
library(rtables)

df1 <- data.frame(
  class = factor(c("D", "A", "A")),
  term = factor(c("dd", "aa", "aa")),
  id = c(1, 2, 3)
)

t1 <- basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("class", child_labels = "visible", split_fun = trim_levels_in_group("term")) %>%
  summarize_row_groups("id", label_fstr = "(n)") %>%
  analyze("term") %>%
  build_table(df1)

df2 <- data.frame(
  class = factor(levels = c("B")),
  id = numeric()
)

t2 <- basic_table() %>%
  split_rows_by("class", child_labels = "visible") %>%
  summarize_row_groups("id", label_fstr = "(n)") %>%
  build_table(df2)

col_info(t2) <- col_info(t1)
t3 <- rbind(t2, t1) 
```

```
> t3
          all obs 
------------------
B                 
  (n)    0 (NaN%) 
A                 
  (n)    2 (66.7%)
    aa       2    
D                 
  (n)    1 (33.3%)
    dd       1    
> sort_at_path(t3, path = c("rbind_rnoot", "*", "class"), scorefun = cont_n_allcols, decreasing = T) 
          all obs 
------------------
B                 
  (n)    0 (NaN%) 
A                 
  (n)    2 (66.7%)
    aa       2    
D                 
  (n)    1 (33.3%)
    dd       1  
```

I want to see a result that looks like this:
```
          all obs 
------------------
A                 
  (n)    2 (66.7%)
    aa       2    
D                 
  (n)    1 (33.3%)
    dd       1  
B                 
  (n)    0 (NaN%) 
```

author: teckla-gsk

title: Allow Rubin's rules to work in case of `se = NA`?
body:
Sometimes one might want to get point estimates without SE estimation. 

For example, for a responder analysis the analysis model might be a logistic regression for a dichotomized endpoint. One might additionally want the estimated proportion of responders in the two groups and not just the adjusted difference between them in log-odds scale, which is a regression coefficient in the logistic regression used to study significance but not easily interpretable.

This could be done by simply allowing the (user-defined) analysis model to return `se = NA` for the proportions parameters. The pooling function should simply in this case return `NA` for SE, CIs and p-value but still return the pooled point estimate.
author: nociale

title: Feature Suggestion:  scale_x_VISITDY to implement skipping day 0
body:
For communication with the clinical teams, it is often useful to create figures using the CDISC representation of days where day 0 does not exist (the time scale goes from Day -1, 23 hours, 59 minutes to Day 1, 0 hours, 0 minutes).

I have created a set of functions to implement the `trans` for ggplot2 which represents VISITDY (or any --DY variable) where 0 does not exist (actually the way I coded it, 0 becomes -1).  I currently have the function in my semi-private Rsdtm library (i.e. it is public, but I don't advertise its existence), but I think it would be a better fit in xgxr.

What it does is:

* Fold Day 0 to Day -1 (making Day 0 an error is problematic due to the ways that I understand the transformation function is called),
* Never show fractional days,
* Prefer showing weeks (units of 7) when the axis range gets large,
* Always show Day -1 and Day 1 to make it clear that Day 0 was skipped on the axis (when the range of days gets very large, that could be a problem because the text "-1" and "1" would overlap), and
* Show every day for minor ticks (that could be improved when the number of minor ticks gets large).

If interested, I could make a PR to put it into xgxr.

I can also imagine a partner function named something like `as_VISITDY()` that would have an argument of `units` to convert continuous scale numbers to VISITDY numbers and then use that as input like `ggplot(my_data, aes(x=as_VISITDY(TSFD, units="hours"), y=y)) +   Rsdtm::scale_x_VISITDY() + geom_point()`.

Here is an example of its use:

``` r
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data.frame(x=-7:14, y=-7:14), aes(x=x, y=y, label=x)) +
  Rsdtm::scale_x_VISITDY() +
  geom_text()
```

![](https://i.imgur.com/FcYEOEV.png)

<sup>Created on 2021-10-06 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)</sup>
author: billdenney

title: How to manually define exponential RUV and proportional RUV by norm() function?
body:
Dear `nlmixr` team,

I found that additive RUV `cp ~ add(add.sd)` is equivalent to `cp ~ norm(add.sd)` in [userguide book](https://nlmixrdevelopment.github.io/nlmixr_bookdown/vignettes.html)!

How can I define in this way for proportional RUV, I tried `cp ~ norm(cp*prop.sd)` but it doesn't work, with error like that: `Error in nlmixrUIModel(.model, ini, fun) : residual distribution parameter(s) estimates were not found in ini block`. Code is:
```
one.compartment <- function() {
  ini({
    tka <- 0.45 # Log Ka
    tcl <- 1 # Log Cl
    tv <- 3.45    # Log V
    eta.ka ~ 0.6
    eta.cl ~ 0.3
    eta.v ~ 0.1
    prop.sd <- 0.7
  })
  model({
    ka <- exp(tka + eta.ka)
    cl <- exp(tcl + eta.cl)
    v <- exp(tv + eta.v)
    d/dt(depot) = -ka * depot
    d/dt(center) = ka * depot - cl / v * center
    cp = center / v
    cp ~ norm(cp*prop.sd)
  })
}

fit2 <- nlmixr(one.compartment, theo_sd, list(print=0), est="focei")
```
And, with exponential RUV, how can I define it in the model. Is that `log(cp) ~ norm(expo.sd)`?

Thank you for the explanation!
Tien Nguyen.

In the script for xgx_conf_int, the function is coded as follows:

```
if (distribution == "normal") {
    mu <- mean(y)
    qtt <- stats::qt(percentile_value, length(y))
    s_v = sqrt(stats::var(y) / length(y))

    conf_int_out <- data.frame(
      y = mu,
      ymin = mu - qtt * s_v,
      ymax = mu + qtt * s_v
    )
}
```

Could you explain why it is 'length(y)' and not 'length(y) -1' as for a t distribution df should be 'n-1'?

author: thomas-neitmann

title: Update pval calculation for bootstrap percentiles
body:
I spent some time thinking about how we invert the bootstrap percentile CI to derive a p-value. 

The one-sided (upper) 1-alpha bootstrap percentile CI is [q_alpha, Inf] where q_alpha is the alpha quantile [type=6] of the bootstrap estimates. 

The p-value for H_0: theta=0 vs H_A: theta>0 is thus the value alpha for which q_alpha=0 [or the largest such value if multiple q_alpha=0, or 0 if all bootstrap estimates are > 0, or 1 if all bootstrap estimates are <0]. 

Our current implementation calculates this as p("greater") = (sum(est<0)+1)/(length(est)+1)) which I took from [Efron and Tibshirani, 1994, page 214-215; adding +1 to comply with the percentile bootstrap definition of Davison and Hinkley, 1997]. 
I believe, this is exactly correct according to the explanation above if and only if exactly one bootstrap estimate is equal to 0. 
If all bootstrap estimates are !=0 [which is the typical case], I think it is conservative and never off by more than 1/(B+1). As 1/(B+1) is very small for large B, this should not be a practical concern.  
If many bootstrap estimates are exactly = 0 [which should not really occur in practice for reasonable data], then the current calculation is more problematic. In particular, in the extreme case where all bootstrap estimates are exactly = 0, then the current calculation gives p("greater")=1/(B+1) which does not make sense. 

Therefore, I have thought about how to improve this to also give correct values in such extreme cases and my current function of creating one-sided p-values is below. Unfortunately, it is more involved than I hoped...
 
The two-sided p-value would be calculated as before with truncation at 1 because it is still possible that both one-sided p-values are >0.5 in case of tied bootstrap estimates at 0. 

I would really appreciate if either of you could think this through again carefully to make sure that I haven't messed anything up and then incorporate it in the next release. Thanks!

```
pval_percentile <- function(est){
  # Determines the (not necessarily unique) quantile (type=6) of "est" which gives a value of 0
  # From this, derive the p-value corresponding to the percentile bootstrap via inversion  
  if (all(est==0)){ # non-unqiue solution
    qmin <-0
    qmax <- 1
  } else if (min(est) > 0){ # if 0 below range of est, still give value 0
    qmin <- qmax <- 0 
  } else if (max(est)< 0) { # if 0 above range of est, still give value 1
    qmin <- qmax <- 1 
  } else if (any(est==0)){ # non-unqiue solution if multiple est==0 
    quant <- rank(est,ties.method="first")/(length(est)+1) # see ?quantile "type=6" section for explanation
    qmin <- min(quant[est==0])
    qmax <- max(quant[est==0])
  } else { 
    qmin <- qmax <- 
      uniroot(function(q) quantile(est,probs=q, type=6),lower=0, upper=1)$root
  }
  c("pval_less" = 1-qmin, "pval_greater" = qmax)
}
```

author: bundfussr

title: Implementation of method type="BMLMI" - bootstrapped ML MI as in van Hippel & Bartlett
body:
Method is described in van Hippel & Bartlett, Stat Sci 2021 article also available at [https://arxiv.org/pdf/1210.0870.pdf](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1210.0870.pdf).
The methods is based on analyzing D randomly imputed datasets (imputation uses the ML/REML estimator) for each of B bootstrap samples. Estimates are then pooled across the B*D datasets and variance is estimated as per section 8 of the manuscript. 

This is less efficient than using conditional mean imputation for ANCOVA as the analysis method but has the advantage to also be theoretically valid (in the sense of giving correct frequentist inference) for other analysis models.

title: #569 Update derive_agegr_fda function
body:
Hi all, I've updated the `derive_agegr_fda` function to fix #569. It is designed to handle 4 different scenarios depending on the availability of `AAGEU` and `age_unit`:
1 - Both `AAGEU` and `age_unit` missing - Returns an error that units are missing
2 - `AAGEU` missing and `age_unit` specified - Use `age_unit` as unit
3 - `AAGEU` specified and `age_unit` missing - Use `AAGEU` as unit
4 - Both `AAGEU` and `age_unit` specified - Warning and use `AAGEU` as unit

This then uses the unit variable to convert the `AAGE` variable into years so that it can be grouped correctly.
The `derive_agegr_ema` function will also require an update to ensure it groups the ages correctly.

author: kodesiba

title: Decouple execution environment from action, allowing for composition with r-lib/actions
body:
<!-- Thank you for your contribution! -->
<!-- Please describe your issue in as much detail as possible-->

# Motivation

Execution environment is a key part of documenting package behaviors. There is no way we can create a singular environment that is representative of all use-cases. Base OS, system dependencies, R build, etc - all effect execution behaviors.

Likewise, if we want to be able to compose with `r-lib/actions`, we likely want to structure our action the same way. That is, the R installation is its own action, which composes as part of a workflow. Most similar to our action would be the [`R CMD check` action](https://github.com/r-lib/actions/blob/master/check-r-package/action.yaml), which makes use of the R installation configured in a previous action in which to run the checks.

# Options/Considerations

1. Clone scripts from the action repo as part of the action? This seems like a hack, but it would be the most straightforward.
2. Composite/shell action that embeds all steps within a `runs:steps:run:` script. 
3. (1) is a bit messy - we could spin up a separate R package to build the actual report such that the contents of the run step would only need to install the package and run a function from it. Shipping the code as an R package, especially one installed as a `github_remote`, is effectively a clone of the script files, but might be more palatable.

---

Any other suggestions/thoughts?

title: Ability to override stage
body:
In some cases, I would like to override the stage by specifying an environment variable or a parameter to a function.

### Use case:

While creating a release from a non-default branch (eg. `pre-release`), I would create a tag from this branch and assign the tag with a value of `v1.0.0`. While doing so, I have Github Action workflows which are triggered on tag creation and produce artifacts that can be attached to the release (i.e. `v1.0.0`), but the artifacts fail to build successfully.

The artifacts fail to build because, while installing the staged dependencies, the deps are installed from the the default stage (i.e. `main`/`master`), whereas they would have built successfully _if_ the tag had the `@pre-release` suffix in its name.

In this case, I would like to be able to create the tag, but specify in my Github Action workflow that I want to install dependencies from the `pre-release` stage for other repos.

title: Crash after minimization
body:
Tangentially related to #565.

I was trying to find an error with my code, and I ran the below to try to fit it.  As I'm looking at the data I passed in, I made a mistake that I tried to fit subcutaneous dosing without providing any actual SC data.  User error there.  But, the model estimation ran and then it crashed.  The crash seems like it should not happen...

The code I used is below, and I've attached the data file.  [data_simpler.csv](https://github.com/nlmixrdevelopment/nlmixr/files/7341451/data_simpler.csv)


```r
library(tidyverse)
library(nlmixr)

nlmixr_onecmt <- function() {
  ini({
    tfsc <- log(0.5)
    tka <- log(0.001)
    tcl <- log(0.03)
    tv <- log(1.5)
    eta_cl~0.05
    eta_v~0.05
    prop_err <- 0.01
    add_err <- 1
  })
  model({
    fsc <- exp(tfsc)
    ka <- exp(tka)
    cl <- exp(tcl + eta_cl)
    v <- exp(tv + eta_v)
    ke <- cl/v
    d/dt(SC) = -ka * SC
    d/dt(CENTRAL) = ka * SC - ke * CENTRAL
    f(SC) <- fsc
    cp = CENTRAL/v*1e3 # 1e3 is for unit conversion
    cp ~ prop(prop_err) + add(add_err)
  })
}

data_simpler <- readr::read_csv("c:/tmp/data_simpler.csv")

nlmixr(
  object=nlmixr_onecmt,
  data=data_simpler,
  #est="saem",
  est="focei",
  control=list(print=1, outerOpt="bobyqa"), 
  table=list(cwres=TRUE, npde=TRUE)
)
```

This is with R 4.1.0 on Windows 10:

title: Make tooltip distance tolerance setting as a parameter

In some cases the default `0.05` distance tolerance may be to big and tooltips may be displayed for shapes that are not in the plot area, e.g. circles in a legend. Changing tolerance to smaller value can fix the issue.

author: SHAESEN2

title: Allow for changing covariance structure for initializing MCMC and set prior parameter in `method_bayes()`
body: Allow the user to specify a different covariance structure for the MMRM model needed to initialize the fit of the base imputation model using a Bayesian approach. The base imputation model still assumes an unstructured covariance structure, but the MMRM could also be fit using a simpler one. This might be useful when MMRM on the original dataset fails and an error is thrown prior to the MCMC start. In this case, the user could set a simpler covariance structure for MMRM (but not for the MCMC) using, e.g. `method_bayes(..., init_cov = "ar1")`. `method$init_cov` is a parameter that takes the same values as `method$covariance`, but can be specified only for `method_bayes()` and has default value to `"us"`.  By setting `init_cov` differently from `'us'` the user will (1) provide starting values of the MCMC equal to MMRM estimates with simpler covariance structure, and (2) assume that the prior for the covariance matrix is a inverse-wishart distribution with mean equal to a non-unstructured covariance matrix. .

title: Do not error when R CMD check issues a note
body:
@Roche-GSK/admiral-devs Currently all PRs fail because of a Note like this:

```
❯ checking installed package size ... NOTE
    installed size is  7.4Mb
    sub-directories of 1Mb or more:
      data   2.7Mb
      doc    3.9Mb
```

Basically, our package grew a bit too large. We need to think what to do here. A couple of options:

- Move all SDTM datasets into their own package which will become a dependency of admiral.
- Remove a subset of patients from all datasets
- Do not save the ADaM datasets

In the meantime I'll change the `R CMD check` workflow such that it does **not** error when a Note is issued.

body:
can fix with pander, or kableExtra. e.g.

```
library(kableExtra); library(tidyverse)

dt <- tibble(
   Items = c("Item 1", "Item 2", "Item 3"),
   Text_1 = c("Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Proin vehicula tempor ex. Morbi malesuada sagittis turpis, at venenatis nisl luctus a. ","In eu urna at magna luctus rhoncus quis in nisl. Fusce in velit varius, posuere risus et, cursus augue. Duis eleifend aliquam ante, a aliquet ex tincidunt in. ", "Vivamus venenatis egestas eros ut tempus. Vivamus id est nisi. Aliquam molestie erat et sollicitudin venenatis. In ac lacus at velit scelerisque mattis. "),
   Text_2 = c("Duis posuere placerat magna, ac aliquam lorem viverra non. Ut ultrices tempus eros, quis sodales libero commodo non. In non neque ut lacus vestibulum dictum a quis ipsum. ", "Aenean ut justo interdum, laoreet enim nec, viverra eros. Donec vel pharetra nunc. Suspendisse vel ipsum ac lectus semper aliquam ac a orci. Suspendisse libero mauris, egestas semper auctor sit amet, tempor et orci. ", "Phasellus quis neque aliquet, finibus nunc eget, lacinia neque. Sed auctor lectus vel ex scelerisque commodo. ")
)
kable(dt, "latex", booktabs = T,
col.names = c("Item", "Short Title", "Very Very Very Very Very Very Long Title")) %>%
column_spec(2:3, width = "5cm")
```

There is the need for something like [`derive_merged_vars()`](https://github.com/Roche-GSK/admiral/blob/v0.1.0-beta/R/derive_merged_vars.R) (feedback from Clara Beck and Samia).

The reason for removing `derive_merged_vars()` was that it allowed to specify expressions for the definition of the new variable.

One option could be to categorize the expressions and implement separate functions, e.g., a function which just renames the variable, a function which converts from dtc to dt variables, a function which categorizes values, ...

Something like the following should be added to the "Writing Vignettes" vignette.
>All ADSL variables which are required for any derivation are merged to the SDTM dataset before the first derivation. These ADSL variables have to be added to the by variables for derivations which add observations. This ensures that the variables are populated for the new observations. ADSL variables which should be in the final dataset but not required for any derivation are merged to the dataset after the last derivation.
A `adsl_vars` variable should be created at the beginning and be used for the merge and added to the `by_vars` parameter for derivations which add observations.

title: ADVS template findings
body:
Hi @Roche-GSK/admiral-devs 

I've been looking through our ADaM template codes starting with ADVS (to help build my own familiarity with the functions) and found few things which Thomas advised I raise an issue for:

- why do we not keep DOMAIN as default as this is a CDISC required variable?
- advs_params gets created adding the new parameter metadata from the lookup but then this doesn't get used as input in the subsequent step (advs gets used), so MAP, BMI and BSA remain with variables like PARAM blank
- something odd happens with derive_var_basetype() step as the dataset goes from 54839 obs to 32824 and we lose some parameters like TEMP completely because of this

Do we have integration testing for these template programs? As that should spot some of these, whereas function-level unit testing only proves each individual function works. I think we discussed adding some integration testing before to compliment this.

Let me know if I could be of use at all here picking up any actions from this issue, e.g. happy to help with setting up some integration test codes.

title: Formatting Risk Assessment outputs
body:
There may be scenarios where making a nice table from an assessment may be of value - so providing formatting functions for formatting and printing the results of the assessments may be a value add for incorporating the results of the assessments more easily rather than needing post-processing.

For example, the flow could be as follows:

```r
pkg_ref("diffdf") %>% 
  pkg_assess() %>%
  pkg_score() %>%
  risk_table()

```
author: thebioengineer

title: Kaplan-Meier Plot - add_risktable is failing when strata is NULL
body:
#### Issue description
Trying to generate Kaplan-Meier plot without strata variable.
Expectation is when `strata is NULL` in `estimate_KM` still risk table has to be showed considering for ALL records.
But function `add_risktable` is failing when `strata is NULL` in `estimate_KM`

Same behavior observed when strata column has 1 group only. consider `column SAFFL` has 1 group (Y) only

#### Steps to reproduce the issue
2 examples are provided
1. when strata is NULL
2. when strata column has 1 group only

```r
adtte %>%
    estimate_KM(strata = NULL, conf.int = 0.90) %>%
    visr(legend_position = "right", x_unit = "Days") %>%
    add_CI(style = "ribbon") %>%
    add_CNSR(shape = 3, size = 1) %>%
    add_risktable(
        statlist = c("n.risk", "n.event", "n.censor"),
        label = c("At risk", "Event", "Censor")
    )
```

```r
adtte %>%
    estimate_KM(strata = "SAFFL", conf.int = 0.90) %>%
    visr(legend_position = "right", x_unit = "Days") %>%
    add_CI(style = "ribbon") %>%
    add_CNSR(shape = 3, size = 1) %>%
    add_risktable(
        statlist = c("n.risk", "n.event", "n.censor"),
        label = c("At risk", "Event", "Censor")
    )
```

#### What's the expected result?
Risk table to be showed in the plot
-


#### What's the actual result?
```
Error in data.frame(time = survfit_summary$time, strata = base::factor(.get_strata(survfit_summary[["strata"]]),  : 
  arguments imply differing number of rows: 11, 0
```
-


#### Additional details / screenshot
please generate similar to this 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/69159004/137876377-021ad1a6-c203-4f13-af2e-8a295373e9e3.png)

author: waddella

title: Finalise how covtracer is represented in v1.0 of the gh-action
body:
From issue #8

The `covtracer` output here is pretty generic. We can do some filtering if we want to present other information. By default, `NA`s are included for documented objects that are untested. As well, there may be situations where the `test_name` is unknown, but there is still testing code that prompts package execution (often this is test setup code, outside of any `test_that()` call). 

In the `covtracer` README, I include these columns just to illustrate the missingness of code coverage. In a report, I would choose other, more meaningful columns - I would drop `test_name` and `count`, and instead filter out unexported documentation (`filter(is_exported = TRUE)`) to only show untested, exported functions as those are a better indicator of the user contract of a package. Just for the sake of clarity, it might be nice to have a clean "No untested behavior" if the resulting table has no records instead of just showing an empty table.

_Originally posted by @dgkf-roche in https://github.com/insightsengineering/thevalidatoR/issues/8#issuecomment-945941598_

author: esimms999-gsk

title: Nicer error message when MMRM fails in Bayes
body:
When `method <- method_bayes()`, if MMRM fails, th error message that appears is:

`Error in stan_data$R %*% mmrm_initial$beta : requires numeric/complex matrix/vector arguments`

Indeed, `mmrm_initial` is a list of one element: `mmrm_initial$failed` which is `TRUE`.

A nicer error message, like the one we use for analogous case for the `condmean(type = "bootstrap")` methods, would be better:

`Fitting MMRM to original dataset failed`

Also `condmean(type = "jackknife")` does not distinguish between error in MMRM fit in the original dataset or in a leave-one-out sample: the error message is the same and is the following: `Jackknife sample failed`

title: pkg_assess output inconsistency between one and multiple packages
body:
The documentation for pkg_assess indicates that the output should be a tibble: 

https://github.com/pharmaR/riskmetric/blob/7fca65c4e4ec588e0685cd608f3c19fee8501bc9/R/pkg_assess.R#L140

However, if a single package reference is generated, a "list_of_pkg_metric" is returned (via `pkg_assess.pkg_ref`)
If you want to maintain this behavior for internal uses, it may be good to create an internal function and then set the exported function to return a tibble so it is consistent with `pkg_assess.list_of_pkg_ref` and `pkg_assess.tbl_df`.

author: anajens

title: gen_reljoin_table doesn't respect variables with the same name as before
body:
If in a relational table I generate a variable that already exists in the base data set, the original will be kept; I this is due to the behaviour of cbind.data.frame (https://github.com/Roche/respectables/blob/e0c0f31d55c47baa9f047a87a68bfd68e05b438a/R/create_data.R#L110).

Example:

```
DM <- tribble(
  ~USUBJID, ~DOMAIN,
  1, "DM",
  2, "DM"
)

join_fun <- rand_per_key("USUBJID","DM", mincount = 0, maxcount = 5, prop_present = 1)
AE_join_recipe <-  tribble(~foreign_tbl, ~foreign_key, ~func, ~func_args,
                           "DM", "USUBJID", "join_fun", list())

AE_recipe<- tribble(
  ~variables,       ~dependencies,      ~func,               ~func_args,
  "DOMAIN",          NULL,              rep_n,               list(val = "AE"),
  
)



AE <- gen_reljoin_table(AE_join_recipe, AE_recipe, db = list(DM = DM))
```

author: bundfussr

title: Add conservative adjustment if get_jackknife_draws fails for a leave-one-subject-out dataset.
body:
For method_condmean(type="jackknife"), it may occur that the estimator fails for only one or very few leave-one-subject-out datasets. Currently, the method fails altogether in this setting and this is ok for 99.9% of the cases, as this should be extremely rare. However, it still seems reasonable to build in a relatively conservative handling of this "worst case scenario" to avoid complete failure.

My proposal is to:
a) Add a tolerance threshold which by default is 0 but allows up to x% jackknife failures.
b) If the MMRM/estimator fails on a leave-one-subject-out datasets, treat it as follows: 
    - the corresponding draws, imputed dataset and estimators are NA/NULL
    - for the jackknife SE calculation, the estimators for all failed leave-one-out dataset are conservatively set  as equal to the observed estimator amongst all leave-one-out datasets which didn't fail and which had the largest absolute distance to the estimator from the original dataset.

title: Create dthdtc and dthfl
body:
DTHDTC and DTHFL need to be created.

DTHFL is "Y" when a death occurred, and "N" otherwise. 

DTHDTC is the date time when death occurred. It should be after RFSTDTC, and not ever patient should die. Take a look at ```respectables::rand_posixct()```

You can update `death_date` and `death_flag` to reflect this

author: kieranjmartin

title: Define seq_fun
body:
seq_fun is used to derive vsseq and aeseq. It should be a count variable that ticks up for every record per patient.

E.G.

|USUBJID | SEQ|
|---|---|
|1 | 1|
|1 | 2|
|1 | 3|
|2 | 1|
|2 | 2|
|3 | 1|

The function should return just the numeric vector with the sequence values in it

author: kieranjmartin

title: Derive VSDTC
body:
VSDTC should depend on which visit you are on (you can use VISITNUM for this) and the start date for the patient (RFSDTC). Visits should be spaced out evenly; there may be some variance (13 days after start rather than 14) but Visit 3 should always be after Visit 2!

You can update `date_gen` to solve this

`date_gen` should return a date time variable

title: Filter Panel Module
body:
As a application user
In order to make subpopulation analysis
I want to apply filter and use filtered dataset accross the app modules

Implementation guide:
- Create a module (both server and ui part) - modify `shiny/filter.R` script.
  - UI part
    - add multiple widgets with all levels / range for a given dataset variable.
    - for ADSL: filter on SEX (multichoices radio-button), RACE (same as previously) and AGE (slider).
    - for ADAE: filter on AETERM and ASEQ (both multichoices radio-button)
    - for ADVS: filter on PARAMCD and AVISIT (both multichoices radio-button)
  - server part:
    - apply `dplyr::filter` with choices / range from input for each datasets
    - return a named list with reactive objects containing filtered dataset
    - introduce dependency between datasets so that filtering on demographics variables in ADSL would influence ADAE filitered dataset:
    ```
    ADSL_FILTERED <- dplyr::filter(ADSL, ...)
    ADSL_FILTERED_FINAL <- ADSL_FILTERED
    ADAE_FILTERED <- dplyr::filter(ADAE, ...)
    ADAE_FILTERED_FINAL <- dplyr::inner_join(ADSL_FILTERED, ADAE_FILTERED, ...)
    ADVS_FILTERED <- dplyr::filter(ADVS, ...)
    ADVS_FILTERED_FINAL <- dplyr::inner_join(ADSL_FILTERED, ADVS_FILTERED, ...)
    (return XYZ_FILTERED_FINAL datasets)
    ```
- Note that some logic would be repeated for multiple datasets - using modules could be a good idea to keep the code DRY.

title: Subgroup analysis
body:
Does rbmi already support subgroup analysis?

What is the best way of performing subgroup analysis with rbmi?

If one would like to basically perform a (baseline) subgroup analysis (let's see by gender) of the primary analysis. Is that correct to consider a three-way interaction treatment-visit-gender in the imputation step and a two way interaction 'treatment-gender' in the 'analysis' (ANCOVA) step? Would, in this case, the output from `analysis()` contain the treatment effect with each subgroup (and would then these estimates be pooled in the `pool()` function)?

Once this is solved, should we add an example in the advanced vignette?

author: hamzarahal

title: `expand_locf` convering dates to integer
body:
minimal reprex:
```
x <- data.frame(
    id = as.character(c(1, 2, 2)),
    id2 = as.character(c(1, 2, 2)),
    visit = as.character(c(1, 1, 2)),
    date = rep(Sys.Date(), 3),
    val = 1:3
)

rbmi::expand_locf(
    x,
    id = unique(x$id),
    id2 = unique(x$id2),
    visit = unique(x$visit),
    vars = "date",
    group = c("id", "id2"),
    order = "visit"
)
```

returns:
```
  id id2 visit  date val
1  1   1     1 18928   1
2  1   1     2 18928  NA
3  1   2     1    NA  NA
4  1   2     2    NA  NA
5  2   1     1    NA  NA
6  2   1     2    NA  NA
7  2   2     1 18928   2
8  2   2     2 18928   3
```

Moreover, above code does not work when you take out `id2` variable:
```
> rbmi::expand_locf(
+     x,
+     id = unique(x$id),
+     visit = unique(x$visit),
+     vars = "date",
+     group = c("id"),
+     order = "visit"
+ )
Error in do.call(as_strata, data_sorted[, group]) : 
  second argument must be a list
```

author: koegerr

title: derive_last_dose fails for medications reported as interval
body:
Hi,
the function derive_last_dose() that I want to use for ADAE fails because I have some medication in EX reported as intervals, i.e. the start and end date are not the same. I can see the problem with a time interval spanning multiple days, but it's not ok that the function stops working completely if something is identified. There can be a note and maybe a parameter saying, use the EXENDTC no matter what (as it is done by STREAM) or exclude multiple day intervals. I would actually only exclude intervals over more than one day. You might have an infusion that starts before midnight and finishes the next day. In that case it's totally fine to use EXENDTC.

Thanks,
Sandra

title: RELREC function to link different domains for common needs
body:
Kristian from Novonordisk has interest to work on this once we open up admiral to community contributions so adding this issue as a placeholder for now.

Discussion with Kristian below from Slack:

Kristian Trøjelsgaard Nielsen Oct 21st at 2:59 PM
Hi all, just a question for the @channel.
In my company we often link information from different SDTM domains through SDTM.RELREC. As far as I understand RELREC is a an official domain, but how it is used can depend on data collection and maybe also some company specific trends.
We often link auxiliary information in relation to AE’s when crating ADAE (e.g. information about injection site reactions, medication errors, hypersensitivity etc), but we also use RELREC in many other cases.  
From my point of view I think there could be much to gain by having some wrapper functions that could handle these operations.
Therefore, do other companies frequently use RELREC and do you see this linkage between domains as something that could be standardised into one or more functions?

Ross Farrugia  8 days ago
hi Kristian, we do map RELREC as standard in our SDTM but how it's used in analysis is not currently well standardised here or part of our current SAS macro solution for ADAE. i imagine some simple function to connect conmeds with the AE they were given for could be achieved but the exact analysis needs might end up more often being study-specific there. is there anything in the ADaM IG using this? i didn't check

Kristian Trøjelsgaard Nielsen  4 days ago
Dear @Ross Farrugia
Thanks for your input.
Doing a quick search in the ADaM IG I was not able to find anything about RELREC. However, there are a couple of Phuse papers that describes the use of RELREC (although one of them is rather old)
(https://www.pharmasug.org/proceedings/2011/CD/PharmaSUG-2011-CD08.pdf and https://www.lexjansen.com/pharmasug/2017/DS/PharmaSUG-2017-DS09.pdf)
I therefore imagine that some standard could be followed at least when attempting to link some of the more common domains.

Ross Farrugia  4 days ago
@Kristian Trøjelsgaard Nielsen sounds a good potential for a community effort once we open source admiral. there's probably many gaps like this in the ADaM IG where we're all doing our own approaches (even team by team within companies) so i like the idea to attempt to provide something to standardise at least for the more common needs. feel free to raise a Github issue as a placeholder for now for this and let us know if you'd have interest to work on this later.
FYI @Thomas Neitmann @Alice Ehmann in case you have better advice here.

Kristian Trøjelsgaard Nielsen  1 day ago
Again thanks for the feedback @Ross Farrugia. I think we will most likely try to implement something like this at my organization so we might as well try to design a solution that could feed into Admiral if that is wanted . So yes, I would have the interest to work on this.

Ross Farrugia  1 day ago
absolutely, this is our vision. we're currently working up the process we will follow around contributions, so expect to see this as part of our open source release

Thomas Neitmann  1 day ago
@Kristian Trøjelsgaard Nielsen We'd love to have you contribute to admiral! Let me know if you need any help.

Kristian Trøjelsgaard Nielsen  23 hours ago
That sounds great - I will reach out @Thomas Neitmann when the time allows me to delve into this.

author: emilliman5

title: draws() fails on grouped data.frame
body:
reprex example (taken from the package vignette - see the last call in which I do `dplyr::group_by`)

```
data("antidepressant_data")
dat <- antidepressant_data

dat <- expand_locf(
    dat,
    PATIENT = levels(dat$PATIENT),
    VISIT = levels(dat$VISIT),
    vars = c("BASVAL", "THERAPY"),
    group = c("PATIENT"),
    order = c("PATIENT", "VISIT")
)

dat_ice <- dat %>% 
    arrange(PATIENT, VISIT) %>% 
    filter(is.na(CHANGE)) %>% 
    group_by(PATIENT) %>% 
    slice(1) %>%
    ungroup() %>% 
    select(PATIENT, VISIT) %>% 
    mutate(strategy = "JR")

vars <- set_vars(
    outcome = "CHANGE",
    visit = "VISIT",
    subjid = "PATIENT",
    group = "THERAPY",
    covariates = c("BASVAL*VISIT", "THERAPY*VISIT")
)

method <- method_bayes(
    burn_in = 200,
    burn_between = 5,
    n_samples = 150,
    verbose = FALSE
)

set.seed(987)
drawObj <- draws(
    data = dplyr::group_by(dat, PATIENT),
    data_ice = dat_ice,
    vars = vars,
    method = method
)
drawObj
```

```
Error: The `groups` attribute is not a data frame with its last column called `.rows`.
Run `rlang::last_error()` to see where the error occurred.
```

traceback:
```
> traceback()
20: stop(fallback)
19: signal_abort(cnd)
18: abort(result)
17: validate_grouped_df(.data)
16: group_data.grouped_df(x)
15: group_data(x)
14: setdiff(names(group_data(x)), ".rows")
13: group_vars.data.frame(x)
12: group_vars(x)
11: intersect(group_vars(x), names(new))
10: group_intersect(x, out)
9: `[.grouped_df`(model_df_scaled, , -1, drop = FALSE)
8: model_df_scaled[, -1, drop = FALSE]
7: as.data.frame(designmat)
6: as_mmrm_df(designmat = designmat, outcome = outcome, visit = visit, 
       subjid = subjid, group = ife(same_cov, NULL, group))
5: fit_mmrm(..., initial_values = init_vals, optimizer = opt)
4: fit_mmrm_multiopt(designmat = designmat, outcome = outcome, subjid = subjid, 
       visit = visit, group = group, cov_struct = "us", REML = TRUE, 
       same_cov = same_cov, optimizer = c("L-BFGS-B", "BFGS"))
3: fit_mcmc(designmat = model_df_scaled[, -1, drop = FALSE], outcome = model_df_scaled[, 
       1, drop = TRUE], group = data2[[vars$group]], visit = data2[[vars$visit]], 
       subjid = data2[[vars$subjid]], n_imputations = method$n_samples, 
       burn_in = method$burn_in, seed = method$seed, burn_between = method$burn_between, 
       same_cov = method$same_cov, verbose = method$verbose)
2: draws.bayes(data = dat %>% group_by(PATIENT), data_ice = dat_ice, 
       vars = vars, method = method)
1: draws(data = dat %>% group_by(PATIENT), data_ice = dat_ice, vars = vars, 
       method = method)
```

title: Unit checking should be case INsensitive
body:
Currently checking for the proper units in `derive_param_*()` functions is case sensitive which leads to annoying errors such as this one.

```
Error: It is expected that HR is measured in beats/min.
In the input dataset it is measured in `BEATS/MIN`
```

Let's make the check case insensitive and ensure that these kind of error do *not* appear.

title: R is aborted when fitting a 1-compartment model
body:
Hi,

This is a Mac user. I changed to a new MacBook Pro with R v4.0.5 (2021-03-31) -- "Shake and Throw".

RxODE v1.1.1 was installed.

nlmixr v2.0.5 was installed by running install.packages("nlmixr"). I did not install the development version.

When I run the following:

Load libraries

library(ggplot2)
library(RxODE)
library(nlmixr)

str(theo_sd)
ggplot(theo_sd, aes(TIME, DV)) +
geom_line(aes(group=ID), col="red") +
scale_x_continuous("Time (h)") +
scale_y_continuous("Concentration") +
labs(title="Theophylline single-dose", subtitle="Concentration vs. time by individual")

one.cmt <- function() {
ini({
tka <- .5 # log Ka
tcl <- -3.2 # log Cl
tv <- -1 # log V
eta.ka ~ 1
eta.cl ~ 2
eta.v ~ 1
add.err <- 0.1
})
model({
ka <- exp(tka + eta.ka)
cl <- exp(tcl + eta.cl)
v <- exp(tv + eta.v)
linCmt() ~ add(add.err)
})
}
fit <- nlmixr(one.cmt, theo_sd, est="nlme")

I get an error message

parameter labels from comments will be replaced by 'label()'
Error in MEEM(object, conLin, control$niterEM) :
Singularity in backsolve at level 0, block 1

When I try this:

fit <- nlmixr(one.cmt, theo_sd, est="foce")

R is aborted.

What do I need to do? I'd be very grateful!

Tao

author: nociale

title: File space design choices
body:
I enjoyed learning more about `valtools` in today's R/Pharma workshop. I have a better sense of the intent and design of the package. I like how it standardizes the final report, nudges the user to confront requirements and risk assessments, and explicitly links requirements to test cases.

However, I did feel friction when it came to setting up validation workspaces. `valtools` creates a unique, complicated, multi-level directory structure of files, many of which need to be edited by hand. Because of this and #214, I found myself constantly attending to a mental model of the file space, which competed in my brain for the attention I was trying to pay to the iterative process of writing requirements and rendering the final report.

What considerations led to the current design choices? Besides the current helpers for creating files, are there other ways to increase encapsulation and help users like me trust the current abstraction?

IMHO, R Markdown really excels when it simplifies file system. [`fusen`](https://thinkr-open.github.io/fusen/) and [R Markdown driven development](https://emilyriederer.netlify.app/post/rmarkdown-driven-development/) are the best examples I know. And I created [Target Markdown](https://books.ropensci.org/targets/markdown.html) so users of [`targets`](http://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) could just write code chunks instead of remembering paths to script files.

title: Working directory friction
body:
`valtools` seems to require the working directory to be the root of the validation file space, not the root of the package. If I try [this command](https://github.com/FredHutch/R_Package_Validation_Tutorial/blob/05b0c3f0b649e0a84c71d92ae4694673a48fde2b/Materials/Materials-04-Requirements_Report/Materials-04-answer-key.R#L19-L22), but with `name` equal to `file.path("r_pharma_validation", "req1.md")` and my working directory one level up, I get an error and warnings. This took a few minutes to debug during the workshop today.

```r
packageVersion("valtools")
#> [1] ‘0.4.0’
getwd()
#> [1] "/cloud/project/Materials/Materials-04-Requirements_Report"
vt_use_req(
  file.path("r_pharma_validation", "req1.md"),
  username = "useR",
  title = "Requirement 1",
  open = TRUE
)
#> Error: Failed to create validationrequirementsr_pharma_validation/req1.md 
#> Run `rlang::last_error()` to see where the error occurred.
#> In addition: Warning messages:
#> 1: In if (file.exists(item_file_path)) { :
#>   the condition has length > 1 and only the first element will be used
#> 2: In if (!dir.exists(file.path(validation_directory, type))) { :
#>   the condition has length > 1 and only the first element will be used
```
